title: Health Benefits of Chlorella: Nature’s Multivitamin

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Have you heard of the health benefits of chlorella? I’d heard of chlorella before, but never really got into the details of how healthy and beneficial it is for our bodies. This stuff is pretty awesome – so much that it’s referred to as “nature’s multivitamin.” Chlorella is a tiny algae and contains an incredible amount of vitamins, minerals, and other important nutrients, like magnesium and iron. It’s a great source of protein for vegetarians, vegans, or anyone who’s reducing their meat consumption.

Chlorella is also great for treating and preventing numerous conditions and diseases, such as heart disease, diabetes, and cancer. It’s also a great immune booster and detoxifier, with its unique ability to bind to toxins and move them quickly out of the body. 

So I’ve just ordered some chlorella powder online. Here’s the brand I ordered (if you click this link and make a purchase, I may get a little kick back, so thank you! :)): Organic Traditions Chlorella Powder. After some research, I’ve learned the best way to take chlorella powder is to mix a half teaspoon of the powder into a glass of juice, or add it to a smoothie. From what I hear, the taste is pretty strong but not overpowering, especially if you’re using a sweet juice or adding sweet fruits to your smoothie.

To read more about the health benefits of chlorella please follow the link below to continue reading my post over at the Healthy Planet blog!

title: Simple Spring Cleaning Tips for a “Clean Enough” Home

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Have you started your Spring cleaning yet? I’m visiting my mom this week, and we’re planning on tackling some of those necessary cleaning tasks to get her house in tip top shape for the new season. We’ve got a pretty solid plan of attack that we’re confident will help us get through this in one piece, but we weren’t always this optimistic. In planning our cleaning routine, to be honest, we became a bit overwhelmed and felt almost defeated. Thankfully, we got out of our rut, thanks to some wonderful tips we found in an amazing book I came across this past week!

Disclosure: This post contains affiliate links. If you sign up through my links, I may receive a small kick back, which helps me run this site. Thank you for your support! Please read my full disclosure for more information.

Homemaking can be a overwhelming!

Let’s be honest here for a minute. House cleaning can be pretty overwhelming, especially when you’re tackling the daunting task of Spring cleaning. You’re dealing with de-cluttering and organization, getting into areas of your home that haven’t been touched in nearly a year, and ideally, you’re re-tooling your home management strategy to help you keep up on your cleaning tasks for the next year. Add to that the added bonus of having young children around, and you’ve got your work cut out for you!

Another added stress factor that I’ve regularly faced in the past is the idea of the “clean standard” so to speak. For some reason, as homemakers, we tend to overestimate the amount of clean our home really has to be; and in the end, I find this just sets us up for failure. We become overwhelmed because the house is never up to standards…even though it’s pretty spotless, more or less. We end up in a cycle of defeat that leaves us feeling, well…defeated.

So what can we do?

Well, for one thing, we need to simplify our homemaking strategy. We need to work smarter, not harder. We need our homes to be “clean enough.” What “clean enough” means is different for each individual, but once that standard is set, we’re golden!

The super helpful book that I came across is Clean Enough: Simple Solutions for the Overwhelmed Homemaker by Jenni Mullinix. This book is chock full of useful and practical tips to help us realize and accept the fact that perfection is not the standard for successful homemaking. That stress-free homemaking is possible. That “clean enough” really can be “Clean Enough!”

3 Tips to Simplify Your Spring Cleaning

I learned so much from Jenni’s book and have come away feeling so much more confident and inspired in my homemaking. So much that I’ve decided to share some of what I’ve learned to help you get a leg up on simplifying your Spring cleaning strategy.

  1. What are your stress areas? The most helpful tip I came away with (which I’m sure is why Jenni put this in the very first section) was the idea of determining your stress areas. What areas of your home cause you the most stress and overwhelm you the most? In the case of our Spring cleaning, this can be either de-cluttering the house/basement/garage, or the detailed, meticulous dusting that needs to be done, or a deep cleaning of all the floors/baseboards/walls. Whatever it is, make sure that’s what you’re tackling first. That way, it’s done and out of the way before you get bogged down with other stuff.
  2. What is your “clean enough”? For each area of the house that you’re tackling in your Spring cleaning schedule, determine what is considered clean enough for you and your family. Do you really have to scrub down all the walls from top to bottom, or is t ok to just spot clean the scuff and crayon marks? What about all that those extra clothes bursting out of your closets and drawers – will you be boxing them, donating them, or adding them to a garage sale? Decide what is realistic and manageable for your family and do just that – nothing more, nothing less.
  3. Simplify your cleaning products: I’m sure you could’ve guessed that I would pick this tip from the book, eh? 😉 I’ve written quite a few posts on homemade cleaners using all-natural, non-toxic ingredients, and Jenni’s tips in this section are right in line with our philosophy at Nature’s Nurture. Simple is better – better for our bodies, better for our pocketbooks, better for our environment. Jenni also includes some printable recipes for homemade cleaners towards the end of the book. If you focus on using just two or three cleaners, as opposed to the plethora of products that are marketed to us, your routine should go much more smoothly. 🙂

Of course, Jenni’s book focuses on so much more than these three areas, but as most of us are getting into the Spring cleaning spirit (right?), I thought these inspiring and helpful tidbits would help get us started on the right foot. Here’s a sample of what else you’ll find in the book that changed my entire view on simplified cleaning:

  • Encouragement for you in your role a a homemaker
  • Suggestions for improving your management skills
  • Directions for creating acheivable cleaning standards
  • Ideas for getting housework done with young children
  • Step-by-step instructions for decluttering your home
  • Tips to help you clean smart, not hard
  • Simple laundry solutions to make your life easier
  • “Think It Through” questions & “Follow Through” suggestions at the end of each chapter
  • Printable natural cleaning recipe cards and labels
  • Inspirational quotes to print,  frame and display in your home
  • Recommended resources to help you become a less-stressed homemaker
  • And so much more!

If you’re feeling overwhelmed with your homemaking tasks and are looking for a guide to get you on the right track, this book is totally worth it! It’ll leave you feeling encouraged, inspired, and confident in your ability to truly manage your home with ease, comfort, and the knowledge that perfection isn’t necessary – “clean enough” is.

Ready to Have a “Clean Enough” Home?

You can purchase Jenni’s book Clean Enough: Simple Solutions for the Overwhelmed Homemaker for just $4.99 and be on your way to a simpler, easier, more manageable cleaning routine.

Jenni’s book is also included in this week’s Ultimate Homemaking eBook Bundle Sale, featuring 97 eBooks for just 29.97 PLUS over $140 in bonuses! That’s right, from now through Saturday, May 4th, 2013 you can get your hands on Jenni’s book as well as 96 other eBooks for under $30!

The bundle includes books and eCourses on topics like cleaning and organization, homeschooling, frugal living, health and fitness, and so much more. You can purchase the bundle here, or you can read more of the details of what’s included.

Jenni’s book alone is valued at $4.99. If you’re interested in the other 11 books in the Home and Property list of this bundle, you’d pay over $80! But for just $29.97 you can get Clean Enough, plus 11 more books on cleaning and organizing, in addition to 85 other eBooks and eCourses!

title: The Homegrown Collective: Sustainable Subscription Boxes {Review}

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Disclosure: There are affiliate links in this post. If you sign up through my links, I will receive a small kick back, which helps me run this site. Thank you for your support! Please read my full disclosure for more information.

Have you been hearing a lot about those monthly subscription boxes lately? There are quite a few companies out there, and I’ve always been interested in trying one out. So when I had the chance to try out a box from The Homegrown Collective, I was more than thrilled!

The Homegrown Collective, like many of the other subscription boxes, sends out a new box every month that focuses on a different theme. But what makes The Homegrown Collective different from other subscription boxes, and it’s one of the reasons I really love this company, is that their boxes don’t just contain a collection of products for you to try. No, their boxes (called Green Boxes) contain items that help promote self-sufficiency, sustainability, and environmental stewardship.

For example, some past Green Boxes have included a mushroom growing kit, DIY cheese kit, and DIY homemade cough syrup. At Nature’s Nurture, we’re HUGE fans of self-sufficiency and sustainability, and I’m always looking for ways to make things at home instead of buying them from the store – in case you can’t tell from my posts! 😉 So finding out about The Homegrown Collective was pretty awesome!

This month, the April Green Box contained a Kombucha Brewing Kit – this could not have come at a better time because I was just telling my husband that we need to start getting into kombucha! If you’re not familiar with kombucha, it’s a fermented, sweetened probiotic beverage that promises a whole bunch of amazing health benefits, from detoxification and digestive health, to immune support. Hmmm, maybe I’ll do a post on that soon!

When the box came in the mail, I was literally jumping up and down for joy because I was so excited to see what’s inside! When I first opened the box, I was very pleasantly surprised by the simple, yet elegant packaging. The contents were wrapped in brown paper and everything inside was packed and padded using just shredded brown paper. I absolutely love simple, eco-friendly packaging!

This is what was inside my Green Box – everything needed to brew my first batch of kombucha: 

  • SCOBY Starter (Symbiotic Culture of Bacteria and Yeast)
  • 1/2 gallon mason jar
  • Black Tea Blend
  • Relaxation & Healthy Tea Kombucha Boosters
  • Organic Ginger Root
  • pH sticks, cloth cover, rubber band

Also included was some information cards to tell you about kombucha and its health benefits, the tea blend and boosters, and complete instructions for exactly how to brew the kombucha. Everything was very easy to read and understand, and was presented in such a pleasant way. 

Unfortunately, I haven’t yet had a chance to actually try brewing that first batch of kombucha, since we’ve been traveling a lot these past few weeks. But once we get home in a couple of weeks, I’m so excited and feel so confident about trying to do this! I can’t wait to experiment with different flavor combinations and to take that very first sip!

I’m also very excited to see what’s coming up in their future Green Boxes. I think kombucha and DIY cheese are my favorites so far!

The Homegrown Collective is definitely something you’ll want to try out if you’ve been interested in those subscription boxes and don’t know where to start. The Homegrown Collective is it, because they provide more than just a box of sample products; they professionally curate their boxes to include seasonally relevant items to help you make everyday a little more green.

Where to Sign Up

Because The Homegrown Collective utilizes a “group buying” strategy, they only curate seasonal items and pass on the savings to you! They have different subscription levels (month-t0-month, 3-months, 6-months, and 12-months) and their prices seem very affordable. I’m pretty sure if I tried to source the items in my kombucha box on my own, it would’ve cost more than the $39 for a 1-month subscription. And they have a 100% money-back guarantee so it’s definitely worth a try!

 You can sign up for a subscription right on their website. And you can use the coupon code GREENMOM10 to get $10 off your first box!

And be sure to keep up with them at the following links for more information, giveaways, and more!

Website | Facebook | Twitter | Pinterest

Are you interested in trying out a subscription with The Homegrown Collective? What’s your favorite past Green Box? What do you hope to see from them in the future?

title: Health Benefits of Chia Seeds: The Ancient Superfood

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
If you haven’t heard of chia seeds yet, you probably think I’m talking about those weird character plants from the ’90’s – Chia Pets. At least that’s what I think of ;). But that’s not at all what we’re talking about here. Chia seeds are actually an ancient superfood that comes from, and has been used for centuries by, the Aztec and Mayan peoples of South America. 

Chia seeds are a complete protein, with a perfect balance of omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids – just like hemp seeds! They’re also high in fiber, naturally gluten-free, and very easy to digest, so they can be eaten in their raw, whole form. Chia seeds can provide a boost of energy, strength, and endurance, which explains why they’re so popular in the natural health and athletics world.

Health Benefits of Chia Seeds

These tiny little grains are good for the heart, the digestive tract, and even for weight loss! I’m sharing info about these health benefits and much more on the Healthy Planet blog today, so be sure to check out that post for all the amazing health benefits of this ancient superfood at the link below!

The Health Benefits of Chia Seeds

 

How to Use Chia Seeds

Chia seeds are a very interesting seed with some weird properties. In their raw form, they’re tiny beads about the size of a sesame seed, and can be sprinkled on just about anything, from salads, to yogurt, to cereal…I’ve even added them to smoothies and stir-fries! They have a very mild flavor so they don’t alter the taste of whatever you’re using them in, which is great!

What makes them interesting is their ability to absorb liquids (they can hold up to 10 times their weight in water!), so when mixed with water or juice, they really expand and take on this gel-like texture. This feature makes them a great replacement for eggs in baked goods, for people who are avoiding eggs for dietary reasons. You simply mix 1 tablespoon of chia with 3 tablespoons of water and let it sit for 15 minutes before stirring and adding to your recipe.

There’s also a recipe on the back of my bag of chia seeds for a simple chia seed drink, which basically calls for mixing a tablespoon of chia seeds into a glass of juice, and letting it sit for 15 minutes before stirring and drinking it. I haven’t tried that yet but it’s supposed to be a great health boost to start your morning!

Again, to learn more about those wonderful health benefits of this perfect food, please check out the link below for my full post!

The Health Benefits of Chia Seeds

Have you ever tried chia seeds before? What’s your favorite way to use them?

title: Natural Spring Cleaning with Plant Therapy Essential Oils

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Spring is here! Spring is here! Spring is HERE!

I’m quite excited, if you can’t tell, because this winter was so darn long, but Spring has sprung and there’s not going back now. 🙂

Our garden is going in a little late this year, as we’ve been (and will be) traveling for a bit, so that’s going to have to wait. But what I have been working on is doing some Spring Cleaning, trying to get this house freshened up and ready for the new season!

I’ve posted quite a few natural cleaning recipes here over the past year, and it’s no surprise that many of them contain not only simple, natural ingredients, but also essential oils. I love essential oils and use them for just about everything – including cleaning our home – because they have disinfecting properties and they leave the house smelling absolutely wonderful.

When Plant Therapy contacted me about trying some of their oils, I quickly jumped at the opportunity. I’d never heard of their company before, but after reading more about them on their website and Facebook page, I knew I wanted to work with them!

Plant Therapy Essential Oils Review

14 Essential Oil Set – Top Singles. Includes Oils of Bergamot, Clary Sage, Cinnamon, Eucalyptus, Grapefruit, Lavender, Lemon, Lime, Patchouli, Peppermint, Rosemary, Spearmint, Orange & Tea Tree.

 

Plant Therapy sent me their awesome Top 14 Essential Oils Set – it contains oils I use on a regular basis, some that I’ve tried a few times, and some that I’ve only heard about but haven’t yet had the chance to try out. This was super exciting for me, as I’m always up for trying new oils in different ways!

First, let me say that I love Plant Therapy’s super simple, yet elegant packaging. The oils come in a simple cardboard box with a small layer of foam to protect the bottles, and a cute little elastic bow to hold the box closed. That’s it. No extra, wasteful packaging or paper, etc. The box was shipped in a thick, padded envelope, but that was it. I love when companies use minimalist principles in their packing and shipping!

Spring Cleaning and Other Recipes

The essential oils I’ve been using for my Spring Cleaning include lavender, orange, peppermint, and tea tree. So I used these in everything from my homemade laundry detergent and dryer sheets, to my all-purpose cleaner, my foaming hand soap and I even made a fresh batch of my anti-bacterial spray.

Now, I’ve used a few different essential oil brands in the past, and I even have a favorite brand for each specific oil. But I can tell you that I’m very pleased with the high quality of Plant Therapy’s oils. They smell amazing, and sometimes even better than my previous favorites. The lavender and orange, specifically, have a cleaner, more vibrant scent – and those are my favorites!

From Plant Therapy:

Plant Therapy believes in the power of essential oils, and know of their incredible benefits, we want them to be used in as many households as possible. Plant Therapy was founded with one goal in mind… we want to provide the highest quality essential oils (and accessories) at a price that everyone can afford. Plant Therapy provides oils that are 100% pure, undiluted and therapeutic grade. We source each oil from top suppliers around the world, buy in large volume, and negotiate the best prices possible. We then pass those savings on to you, the consumer!

In addition to my Spring Cleaning, I also wanted to try out some of the other oils, so I made up a new batch of my homemade deodorant. I used the lavender and tea tree oils for one batch, as usual, but I also added some patchouli for another batch because it has an earthy, fruity scent. Patchouli also has antiseptic and antimibrobal properties, making it a great deodorant!

And since I’m pregnant, I just had to try some of the tips from my Essential Oils for Pregnancy post! I’ve been having some neck pain and stiffness, so I mixed a couple drops of bergamot and lavender into some coconut oil and gave myself a nice neck massage. Wow! I’ve never used bergamot oil before, but it was a very nice complement to the lavender oil, for a soothing, relaxing massage. Bergamot is good for stress and anxiety, so it’s a great addition to your relaxing bath and massage oil blends.

I also really like that they list the uses and benefits of the oils very clearly on the side of every bottle. That way, the info is right at your fingertips so you don’t have to go fumbling around looking it up online or searching through a book.

The only thing I didn’t like about these oils was how quickly they came out of the bottle when I was adding them to my recipes. I’m used to a slow, controlled drip, allowing me to carefully count each drop. But Plant Therapy’s oils come out much more quickly, that sometimes it was hard to count the drops. Of course, this is an issue with the bottles, and not the oils themselves, but I still thought I’d mention it just so you’re aware.

I’m really impressed by the quality of Plant Therapy’s oils. They’re 100% pure and natural, of therapeutic grade and free from any chemicals or pesticides. If you’re just starting to get into essential oils, or if you’re a seasoned pro, you may want to give them a try next time you’re shopping for some oils, as they’re very affordable!

Where to Buy Plant Therapy Essential Oils

You can buy Plant Therapy essential oils right from their website. They carry a very large selection of different oils sourced from around the world. They also carry lots of cool accessories like diffusers, cases, books, and empty roll-on bottles to create your own blends. Another great product they offer is their synergy blends, which I’m very interested in trying!

And from now until May 14th, 2013 Plant Therapy is offering all Nature’s Nurture readers a coupon for $10 off your purchase of $25 or more – just enter the code naturesnurture10 at checkout! (Coupon cannot be used towards the purchase of Gift Certificates and only one coupon per customer.)

Be sure to check out Plant Therapy at the links below for more information, discounts, giveaways and more!

Website | Blog | Facebook

How to Win Plant Therapy Essential Oils

Plant Therapy was also kind enough to sponsor a giveaway for our readers! That’s right, one lucky reader will win a Top 14 Essential Oils Set (valued at $54.95) of their own! Just come back on May 1st, 2013 for the Green Your Mom Giveaway Hop! The contest will be open worldwide! The best way to be notified when the giveaway goes live is to subscribe to our weekly newsletter or follow us on Facebook and Twitter.

title: 5 Ways to Celebrate Earth Day Everyday!

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Photo Credit: RC::mac / Flickr

Happy Earth Day everyone! 

I was racking my brain trying to come up with ideas for what to post today, but after some thought, I realized something. If we are truly honoring the earth and caring for it, this should be something we’re doing everyday, right? No doubt, Earth Day is a special day in and of itself as it allows us to share ideas and bring awareness to the issues that need to be addressed in our world; but at the same time, it’s also a day that we can reflect on the things we are doing and the areas that we can improve in our own homes, with our own families.

So today I want us to think about how we can honor the earth each and everyday. It’s those little things, the everyday things, that really matter in the end. It’s the sustainable acts, the acts we make into habits, the ones we teach our children so they may grow up and have a better world than we do.

I polled some of our Facebook friends for ideas on what we can do regularly to help honor and care for the earth. It’s no surprise that their responses were right in line with what I had in mind for this post. What we came up with is a list of some simple, easy things we can all do everyday!

  1. Pick up trash: At the beach, in your neighborhood, in a parking lot, anywhere! Seriously, this is the most common answer and one of the easiest things we can all do right now. It requires nothing more than a few minutes and a trash bag. If you feel grossed out by picking up trash from the street, bring along a pair of gloves to wear. One reader even said she picks up cigarette butts – which is something I’ve actually never done!
  2. Conserve energy: When you’re out of the house all day, a great way to save energy is to turn down the heat/air by a few degrees. Not only does it save energy, but your heating/cooling costs will also drop. And when the weather is warm, turn off that A/C, crack some windows and doors and let the clean, fresh air waft through your home. It’s so much better for your health than breathing in stagnant air all day. Another good tip is to remember to turn off the lights in rooms that you’re not using – become the light police! 🙂
  3. Green your lawn care: It’s officially Spring! The grass is green, your gardens are going into their beds, and eventually weeds will start popping up. Ditch the chemical pesticides and fertilizers and instead, opt for for more natural forms of lawn care. There are plenty of organic lawn care products on the market today and also some great homemade recipes online as well.
  4. Recycle and compost: Most areas today have a city-run recycling program, many with curbside pickup, which makes this job so much easier! And if you’re lucky to live in a city that has a composting program, like we do here in Toronto, you’re in even better shape! Keep in mind when out shopping, to try to look for products that come in recyclable or compostable packaging, so you divert as much waste away from the landfill as possible.
  5. Go local or grown your own: Try to source your produce, meats, and animal products from local farms and farmer’s markets. Not only does this support the local economy, it also ensures your food hasn’t traveled to far to get to you. But what’s even better than that? Why, growing your own, of course! Try planting a small vegetable garden this year – even if you live in an apartment, container gardening can be very successful on your balcony. And if your city allows it, you can even try raising some backyard chickens!

BONUS! – Ditch the paper: Everywhere you look, you see disposable versions of just about everything – plates, cups, napkins, disinfecting wipes, diapers, etc. One of the best things (although not the easiest at first!) we can do for the earth is to cut back, and eventually eliminate our dependence, on these disposable products. Instead, let’s move in the direction of reusable and cloth products to replace the paper products that we’ve become so dependent on. This definitely requires baby steps because you’ll become overwhelmed if you attempt to do everything at once.

In our house, we’ve ditched the paper towels and instead, cut up old rags and use them as little napkins for quick cleanups, especially with our toddler. We also never buy disposable dinnerware – even when we go out on a picnic. We just bring our set of stainless steel dinnerware that we found at a thrift store years ago.

There are so many other ways to ditch the paper and disposables, from cloth napkins to cloth diapers, and even reusable toilet paper (I know – it sounds weird, but it’s actually pretty cool). My friend Sara at My Merry Messy Life has quite a few tutorials for these ideas and more, and she’s written up a great round up post for Earth Day! Check out her awesome post here: How To Ditch Paper Products and Go Paper Free

So tell me, what do you do regularly with your family to honor and care for the earth everyday, not just on Earth Day?

title: Hemp: Nature’s Most Perfect Food

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
When I mention hemp around some people, I get weird looks as if I’ve uttered something completely taboo. Because hemp comes from the Cannabis sativa plant – the same plant that marijuana comes from – it’s understandable that the former would get confused for the latter. But unlike marijuana, hemp does not contain the high levels of THC which are responsible for creating the high.

Hemp has so many amazing industrial uses and is actually the world’s oldest and most versatile crop! It’s been used for centuries to make clothing, food, fuel, paper, plastic, and other building materials. In fact, there’s reportedly over 25,000 known uses for hemp. It’s stronger and more durable than any other plant derived fiber and has the potential to replace petroleum products like plastics.

Nature’s Perfect Food

As a food, hemp is known as “nature’s most perfect food” because it contains the perfectly balanced ratio of essential fatty acids omega-3 and omega-6 that nature intended (1:3 ratio). It contains all 10 essential amino acids, making it a complete protein. Not only that, but it has no known allergens and is one of the best, quality sources of plant-based protein, making it a great choice for those following a vegan, gluten-free, or dairy-free diet.

The best thing about hemp products? They’re 100% sustainable and are naturally resistance to pests, meaning they are grown without pesticides and contain no GMO’s! It also doesn’t deplete the soil and uses about half as much water as other agriculture crops. 

How to Add Hemp to Your Diet

Photo: apathyduck / Flickr

Hemp food products come in many forms, including hemp seeds and hemp protein powder. My favorite brand for these is the Nutiva Organic Shelled Hemp Seeds and the Nutiva Organic Hemp Protein. I use the hemp seeds in our yogurt, granola, and on top of salads. I add the hemp protein to our smoothies, milk, batters, or cereal. Hemp has a nice flavor and very nutty taste, kind of like pine nuts or sesame seeds. 

How Hemp Can Benefit Your Health

Since hemp is a super food, its health benefits are too many to list here, but include heart health, brain health, skin health, and it can even aid in weight loss and help control blood sugar levels. I’m guest posting over at the Healthy Planet blog today and sharing more on these help benefits and more! Just click the link below to go to that post – I promise it’ll make you consider buying a bag of hemp seeds or protein this week! 😉

Health Benefits of Hemp

title: Homemade Natural Hand Sanitizer (Alcohol-Free)

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Ever since I’ve embraced this new green lifestyle of mine, there are a few things that I really miss from my old life. Slowly, I’ve been finding ways to find natural alternatives, and a couple weeks ago I finally decided to make some homemade hand sanitizer. This was a big one for me because I used to use the store bought stuff like it was going out of style! I had it at home, I had the travel size one in my purse, and as a former school teacher, you better believe I had a big old bottle of that stuff right on my desk!

But once I started purging my home of the not-so-natural cleaning and personal care products, I sadly had to let go of my beloved hand sanitizer. Of course there’s no substitute for good hand washing, and nothing is more effective at killing germs than a good hand soap and some warm water. But for those times when you need some germ fighting power and you’re nowhere near a washroom, hand sanitizer really does come in handy!

What’s wrong with the store bought sanitizers?

As we discussed in my all natural antibacterial spray post, these products kill nearly all bacteria – good and bad. As effective as those store bought hand sanitizers may be at killing bacteria, they don’t discriminate between good and bad bacteria. Since the good bacteria protects our bodies from infection and helps it to fight off the bad bacteria, it’s a bit counterproductive to kill off those helpful good bacteria, isn’t it? 

Also, the main ingredient in these store bought products is ethyl alcohol – a minimum concentration of at least 60%. As much as I like using alcohol for cleaning and disinfecting, I really don’t like the idea of rubbing alcohol on my hands over and over again since it can be drying to the skin. Alcohol is also very toxic and can be deadly for young children, and with a 60% concentration, I definitely don’t want these hand sanitizers anywhere near my kiddos!

And have you checked the Environmental Working Group’s (EWG) data sheet on Purell Hand Sanitizer (the brand we used to use)? Not only does it have an overall score of 5 (I don’t like using anything with a score higher than 2 or 3), it contains about 10 other questionable ingredients, including artificial fragrance (EWG score of 8) and artificial colors, both of which I try to stay far away from.

So what’s the alternative?

Why, I’m so glad you asked! 😉 There are a ton of homemade versions floating around on the internet, so I kind of took a bit from here and there. The main ingredients we’ll be working with are aloe vera gel, witch hazel, and essential oils. I also added some vitamin E oil to act as a natural preservative and for some skin softening properties.

The witch hazel I used has 14% alcohol by volume. Some brands of witch hazel can have up to 70% alcohol, so look for one with a low alcohol concentration. You may also find one with no alcohol at all at a natural health food store, but I’m confortable with the small amount of alcohol in this one.

Essential oils have anti-bacterial and anti-viral properties, so they’re a great (and necessary!) addition to a homemade hand sanitizer. For this recipe, I’m using tea tree oil and lavender essential oil. The tea tree oil is kind of a must, since it has very potent antimicrobial properties (use at least 0.5% concentration). The lavender oil helps mask the strong scent of the tea tree oil a bit, but it’s also very calming. Other oils you may want to experiment with include lemon, neroli, patchouli, peppermint, ylang ylang, clove, or pine – all of which have antiseptic properties.

Natural Hand Sanitizer
2013-04-18 21:06:20
Homemade, alcohol-free version of commercial hand sanitizer, using the powers aloe vera, witch hazel, and essential oils.
Write a review
Save Recipe
Print
Ingredients
  1. 1 cup pure aloe vera gel (as pure as you can get)
  2. 1 tablespoon witch hazel
  3. 30 drops (1/4 tsp) tea tree oil
  4. 10 drops lavender oil (or essential oil of choice)
  5. 3-4 drops vitamin E oil (optional)
Instructions
  1. In a small glass dish, add the essential oils and stir.
  2. Add the witch hazel and vitamin E oil and stir again.
  3. Add the aloe vera gel and mix very well.
  4. Using a funnel, pour the mixture into your container of choice.
  5. Shake well before using.
Notes
  1. The vitamin E oil helps to soften hands and will extend the shelf life up to 3-4 months. In either case, the sanitizer should be discarded after 6 months.
  2. This recipe filled 3 travel size (3 oz) squirt bottles. To fill just one 3 oz bottle, use 1/3 cup aloe vera, 1 teaspoon witch hazel, 10 drops tea tree oil, and 3 drops lavender oil.
By Sarah @ Nature's Nurture
Nature's Nurture http://naturesnurtureblog.com/
Wordpress Recipe Plugin by Recipe Card
Warnings:

  • As with all products that contain essential oils, please keep in mind that some oils are not recommended for use while pregnant or breastfeeding, and others (like lavender) are known to mimic estrogen in the body and are not recommended for use with boys. So please, research the oils you wish to use before you add them to your recipe.
  • Before working with essential oils, keep in mind that you or a family member may be allergic to certain oils. It’s always a good idea to do a patch skin test by diluting one drop of essential oil in 1 tablespoon of olive oil and applying it to your arm. If there’s no reaction after 24 hours, then you’re good.
  • Although this recipe is safe for adults and young children, I wouldn’t use this (or any sanitizer) on children younger than 2 years of age.

Do you use hand sanitizer when you’re out and can’t wash your hands? What’s your favorite natural brand to use, or do you make your own?

title: Natural Pregnancy: Essential Oils for Pregnancy

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
This post is part 2 of 5 in the series Natural Pregnancy

As if I don’t speak enough about essential oils on here, I’ve found yet another reason to tout their magnificent capabilities – this time, for pregnancy and labor! During my last pregnancy, I didn’t use essential oils at all, although I’d read briefly about the benefits of aromatherapy for labor. This time around, however, I’ve already used them quite a bit, and I’m only half way through this pregnancy!

Essential oils can be used during all stages of pregnancy – from that dreaded first trimester with its morning sickness and fatigue, all the way through to labor and delivery, and even post-partum care! For now, we’ll just focus on pregnancy and leave the labor/deliver and post-partum care for a later post.

Disclaimer: Before we go any further, it’s important to note that essential oils are very concentrated substances and should be used with caution. Although essential oils are completely safe when used properly, many should not be used during pregnancy. The essential oils I mention in this post should only be used if you have a low risk pregnancy, with no history of complications like miscarriage, vaginal bleeding, heart problems, or diabetes. That being said, I’ve done my own research and I encourage you to do the same before deciding if essential oils are for you. And as always, please consult your midwife or doctor before using any of these oils for any of the reasons stated in this post.

Essential Oils for Pregnancy

Stretch Marks and Itchy Skin

Even if you’re blessed not to get many stretch marks during pregnancy, most women do get that irritating itchy skin on their growing belly. Regardless, the tender skin on the belly, butt, and thighs is especially sensitive since it’s constantly stretching and expanding. To help soothe and nourish the dry, itchy skin in those areas, dilute 1-2 drops of mandarin or neroli oil into 1-2 teaspoons of a carrier oil (I like coconut oil or sweet almond oil), and massage into the skin as a daily moisturizer.

Morning Sickness & Headache

The nausea and queasiness that comes along with the first trimester is no joke! Along with other natural morning sickness remedies, essential oils of lemon or lavender can also help. You can either open up the bottle and just smell it, or you may choose to dilute 1-2 drops into 1-2 teaspoons of a carrier oil and massage it into your temples or the back of your neck. I’ve done both and I think I prefer just smelling it straight from the bottle.

Rest and Relaxation

If you can find a moment to take a nice, quiet bath, do it! A soothing bath can be so good for your emotional well-being during this time, and adding some essential oils to the bath water can really help boost the relaxing and de-stressing properties of the bath. With a toddler at home, I haven’t gotten a chance to experience this, but I love the sound of this relaxing bath blend – 2 drops of lavender and 1 drop of ylang ylang added to the bath water!

Even if you don’t have the luxury of enjoying a quiet bath, I can’t say enough about the wonders of a good massage. Just 10 minutes is all it takes to really soothe and relax those sore, achy muscles on your back, neck, and legs. Mix 1-2 drops of either lavender, neroli, or bergamot oil into 1-2 teaspoons of a carrier oil and have your partner give you a nice, relaxing massage. 

Perineal Massage

If your prenatal care is under a midwife, chances are you’ve been encouraged to do this towards the end of your pregnancy. Massaging the perineum daily during the last six weeks of pregnancy can help reduce or prevent tearing and an episiotomy. I did this on and off with my first pregnancy, but was only told to use vitamin E oil. But I’ve been reading quite a bit about adding a drop of essential oil to your carrier oil to help with the process, and this university study showed the benefits of using lavender oil for this massage, so I think I’ll give it a try this time around!

Have you ever used essential oils during pregnancy? What are your favorite oils and how did you use them?

I’ve actually been looking for a natural insect repellent and was so glad to find that MadeOn Hard Lotion also carries a hard insect repellant bar called Bug Block!

You’ve heard me rave of the wonders of MadeOn‘s hard lotion bars (you can read my full review and testimonial here), so I’m confident that their bug repellent will be just as amazing!

For the month of April, when you purchase a family size of MadeOn’s Bug Block, you’ll also a receive a FREE copy of the Family Camping Guide ebook from Katie of Kitchen Stewardship! This ebook promises to show you how to make the most of your frugal family camping trip, even if you’ve got little ones in tow. Everything from getting started, to what to bring, how to meal plan, and even some recipes to get you on your way!

Honestly, I’ve been afraid of the idea of camping now that we have a toddler and I’m pregnant with baby #2, but this ebook actually has me excited about the idea! I’m off to purchase my Bug Block bar and dive into my Family Camping Guide to get ready for the Spring season…whenever it decides to show up here in Toronto. 😉

title: Natural Skin Care from Annmarie Gianni {Review & Sponsor Spotlight}

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Ever since I’ve been using the Oil Cleansing Method to wash my face, I’ve stopped using commercial facial cleansers. I love the oil cleansing method and recommend it to everyone, so it’s no secret that I’m definitely not in the market for any facial cleansers or skincare products.

However, one of the most common questions I do receive on the OCM post has to do with what type of facial cleanser I recommend to use for the nights that you don’t use OCM. Until now, I didn’t really have a straightforward answer; I just sort of pushed in the direction of an all natural cleanser, but never had a brand to really stand behind.

When Annmarie Gianni Skin Care contacted me to try out some of their products, to be honest, I was a bit hesitant at first. Here’s a company which makes skin care products that promise to tackle various skin conditions. How could I honestly review these products knowing that I’ve already posted about using homemade methods to do the same thing? But the more I looked into their company, the more I realized just how awesome their products really are.

What if I told you there’s an all-natural, organic, wild-crafted skin care line that really uses natural ingredients – ingredients that you and I can actually pronounce and have most likely heard of before? Yep, Annmarie Gianni Skin Care is it! I’ve read the ingredient list of every single product on their website and I can assure you that they truly are all natural!

Annmarie Gianni, an author and health advocate, started Annmarie Gianni Skin Care after becoming frustrated with the lack of truly natural skin care products on the market (sound familiar?). She carries a wide line of products ranging from cleansers and scrubs to moisturizers and masks. They contain no artificial ingredients or preservatives, and all ingredients are clearly listed on each package.

Annmarie Gianni Skin Care Review 

For this review, Annmarie Gianni sent me a facial care sample set and a full size coconut body oil. The sample set contains one small sample each of citrus mint facial cleanser, aloe-herb cleanser, coconut honey mask, coconut body oil, rosemary toning mist, neroli toning mist, anti-aging serum, and anti-aging facial oil. The coconut body oil is meant to be used an all-over moisturizer and massage oil.

I still can’t believe how truly natural these products are. The first ingredient listed on each product is “love” – how awesome is that?! 🙂 Each product has a specific purpose and is made for a certain skin type; oily, normal, or aging skin. They smell absolutely wonderful and feel great on the skin. The facial cleansers wash off clean, without leaving the skin feeling dry or tight afterwards. The toning mists are so light and refreshing, and the anti-aging serum and oil really leave the skin feeling soft and smooth.

My absolute favorite sample was the coconut honey mask. This stuff smells so yummy, I just want to eat it. Actually, I did eat it! That’s how natural this stuff is – I took a tiny bit on my finger and just ate it straight. So delicious! This mask leaves the skin so smooth and silky afterwards, I absolutely love it.

My other favorite product is the coconut body oil (pictured at the top of this post). I use this oil every single day. It’s best when applied on damp skin, right out of the shower, and leaves your entire body feeling so soft and hydrated the entire day. It’s great especially for those extra dry areas, like the elbows, knees, and ankles, and I’ve also been using it on my new baby bump to help soothe the dry, itchy skin on my belly! Like all the other products, the body oil also smells wonderful; it’s almost like an all-over body perfume. And I don’t wear perfumes, so it’s actually very nice! 

What do I love most about Annmarie Gianni skin care products? Well, besides their 100% all-natural ingredients and their super yummy scents, I really love that all of their products are packaged in glass containers. They specifically use Miron Violet Glass, which has been shown to preserve and protect natural ingredients for longer. Plastics can leech into products, especially those with highly potent ingredients like essential oils, so I’m very happy to see that AnnMarie Gianni’s products are only packaged in high quality glass – even their sample sizes! Not only that, but it makes their containers completely reusable too! And you know me and my slight obsession with repurposing old containers. 😉

Where to Buy Annmarie Gianni Products

AnnMarie Gianni’s products are popping up in local stores all over the world, including the US, Canada and Europe. So check their store locations to find a retailer near you. Otherwise, you can purchase their products right from their website. They offer sample kits  of their products (just $10 with free shipping!) so you can try them out before buying the full sizes. They also offer travel sets and gift sets for each skin type. Their customer service is really top notch, and you can read more reviews of their products right on each product page. 

Check out Annmarie Gianni at the following links for promotions, giveaways, and more!

Website | Facebook | Twitter

How to Win Annmarie Gianni Products

Annmarie Gianni is also offering one lucky Nature’s Nurture reader the chance to win some all-natural skin care products! Come back on April 9th, 2013 for the 2nd annual Honor the Earth Giveaway Hop to enter for your chance to win a Normal Skin Care Travel Kit valued at $39.95, which includes 4 different products and a sheer carrying case! The contest will run until April 22nd. The best way to be notified when the giveaway goes live is to subscribe to our weekly newsletter or follow us on Facebook and Twitter.

title: Oil of Oregano: Nature’s Antibiotic

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Have you ever bought something that you heard about from others only to let it sit in your cabinet for what seems like 5 years before you finally get yourself to use it?

Yep, happens to me a lot. Most recently, it was a small bottle of oil of oregano. I’d heard so many great things about this oil and was convinced that it must be included in my natural medicine cabinet; but once it found a spot on the shelf, it kind of just stayed there…for about 6 months!

I just didn’t really know what to do with it. After some research and testing, I found out some pretty amazing things about this stuff. Most importantly, that it’s considered “nature’s antibiotic“!

Dr. Cass Ingram, in his book The Cure Is In The Cupboard, lists over 170 conditions that oil of oregano can help treat, including eczema, diarrhea and sinusitis. It can kill bacteria, fungus, yeast, parasites and viruses; and it’s also a powerful anti-inflammatory, pain killer, and antiseptic.

Oil of oregano is very potent and must be diluted with a carrier oil (I use either olive or coconut oil) when applying to the skin. If I’m taking it orally, I like to dilute it in some water or juice. It can also be applied directly under the tongue, as per the directions on the bottle, but I haven’t been brave enough to try that yet. 😉

How to Use Oil of Oregano

I’ve only been experimenting with this oil for a short while so I’ve only tested it on a couple of applications. The results I found from these two tests, however, pushed me to look even more into this amazing oil! Follow the link at the end of this post for the full list of 10 ways to use oregano oil, along with dilution information, and side effects and precautions.

  • Headaches and Migraines: For a minor headache, I like to just hold the bottle under my nose and take in a few long whiffs to allow the fumes to enter up into the sinuses. For a stronger headache or migraine, it can be applied to the forehead, temples, and between the eyebrows.
  • Colds and Sore Throats: We’ve all been sick this past week, so it was the perfect time to test out this oil with a typical cold, which included a sore throat and cough. I tested this on my hubby and gave him 3 drops diluted in his morning juice everyday. By the third day, his sore throat was feeling much better and his head congestion had eased tremendously!

Where to Buy Oil of Oregano

You can most likely find oil of oregano at your local health food store. It’s also available online at Amazon. If you’re in Canada, you can find the brand that I use (Hedd Wyn) on HealthyPlanet.com or from the manufacturer’s website here.

For the full list of the top 10 ways to use oregano oil, including how to dilute it, and its safety precautions, please follow the link below for this week’s post at Healthy Planet!

10 Ways to Use Oil of Oregano

You know me, I’m not a fan of antibiotics. I think they’re too harsh, grossly overprescribed, and can prevent the body from doing what it was made to do: heal itself. That’s not to mention the long list of side effects, some chronic, that can arise in those who take antibiotics. Nope, not for me.

Don’t get me wrong though. Of course I think antibiotics are one of the greatest discoveries in modern history and have saved countless lives over the years; but in today’s overmedicated, “gotta treat everything with a pill” society, we’ve lost touch with nature’s true power to heal the body. Nature’s antibiotic is definitely something I’d try before man’s antibiotic. 🙂

Have you heard of or tried oil of oregano before? If so, how have you used it in your home?

title: Why And How To Eat More Kale (Plus Recipes!)

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
A couple of weeks ago, I shared on my Facebook page and Instagram feed that I’ve finally taken the plunge and picked up some kale at the store. I don’t know why it had taken me so long – what was I so afraid of? The taste? The texture? Mehh, I was just being a baby. And in my infantile state, I asked you, my wonderful readers, for your favorite ways to eat kale. 

Man, the response was absolutely amazing! Over the next few days, we had a huge thread on Facebook with all sorts of yummy sounding treats and entrees that use this wonderfully nutritious leafy green! 

Health Benefits of Kale

And while we’re on the subject, what makes this leafy green so healthy anyway? Let’s just keep it simple with an easy list, shall we? Kale is a nutritional powerhouse and one of the healthiest vegetables on the planet because it’s:

  • Low in calories and high in fiber – 1 cup has 36 calories and 5 grams of fiber.
  • High in iron – more iron per calorie than beef.
  • Filled with antioxidants – like carotenoids and flavonoids.
  • High in calcium – more calcium per calorie than milk.

Kale is also high in vitamins A, C, and K, is a great anti-inflammatory food, and supports a healthy heart. It’s also a great detox food to help flush out toxins from the body and keep the liver healthy and functioning well.

How to Use Kale

This is where our awesome readers come in. I asked and you guys delivered! So here are some the most popular ways to use kale, all gathered from our Facebook and Instagram pages:

  • Use it in place of spinach in recipes (soups, pastas, casseroles, mashed potatoes, beans, crock pot meals, etc.)
  • Add it to a green salad (massage it first to soften it up)
  • Add it to your green smoothies

    Kale Sautéed in Coconut Oil & Salt

  • Add it to your sandwiches
  • Make kale chips (see recipes below)
  • Steam it
  • Juice it
  • Sautée it with coconut oil and salt
  • Stir fry it with other veggies
  • Use in place of lettuce wraps

How to Prepare Kale

I won’t go into too much detail here because I’ll share a few links which will do this better than I can. But what I can say is that since kale is a leafy green, and most leafy greens are high in pesticide residue, try to source organic kale (or grow your own!). However, if you’re unable to, just make sure to clean it very well by soaking the leaves in water for a few minutes, agitating them to shake off any dirt, and lightly massaging them to remove any residues.

Also, the center stem is quite bitter, so when trimming and chopping kale, just slice down each side of the stem, remove it and toss it in the compost.

Preparing Kale from I Love Kale

      • Drying Kale in the Dehydrator
      • How to Freeze Kale
      • How to Massage Kale

Kale Recipes

Alright, this is the fun part! I’ve categorized some of the best recipes below for your viewing pleasure!

Soups & Salads

  • White Bean and Kale Soup from The Vintage Mom
  • Kale, Potato, Pea and Anise Soup from I Love Kale
  • Kale Salad With Creamy Dressing from On The Home Front
  • Kale Salad With Apple, Avocado, and Cranberry from Brittleby’s Corner
  • Portuguese Chourico and Kale Soup from Rachel Ray

Sweet Potato Kale Pizza from All Things Moms

Mains

  • Cheesy Baked Eggs with Kale from Eco-Babyz
  • Sweet Potato Kale Pizza from All Things Moms
  • Braised Kale from Mamal Diane
  • Simple Spaghetti with Kale, Lemon and Garlic from Hogwash

Chips

  • Baked Kale Chips from On The Home Front
  • Organic Kale Chips w/Nutritional Yeast from Brittleby’s Corner
  • Spicy BBQ Kale Chips from The Raw Chef
  • Raw Vegan Cheesy Garlic Kale Chips from Happy Mothering

Kale Smoothie with Strawberries from Built Lean

Smoothies & Juices

  • Lemon Ginger Green Juice With Kale from Powerful Mothering
  • Green Lemonade from Creative Green Living
  • Kale Smoothie with Strawberries from Built Lean
  • Kale Smoothie for Babies from Positively Amy

title: Homemade Foaming Hand Soap

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
I love the idea of foaming hand soap but ever since we switched to using Dr. Bronner’s castile soap in our dispensers, I’ve never been able to actually try using foaming soap. Most of the ones on the market are not natural and contain a whole bunch of nasty chemicals, and I haven’t been able to find a truly all-natural foaming soap.

When I started doing a little research on foaming hand soap, I learned something crazy! Those little foaming soap dispensers you see at the store? They’re actually filled mostly with water and just a little bit of soap. It’s actually the dispenser that does all the work! So these companies are charging full price for a dispenser of soap that’s about 80% water!

Well, you know what that means, right? I just had to try making my own! I had an old foaming soap dispenser that I’ve been saving for a while, so I grabbed it and got to work. I also found these cute foaming soap dispensers on Amazon in lots of fun colors!

I filled up the bottle about 3/4 with distilled or purified water. Then I filled it almost to the top with Dr. Bronner’s castile soap (I used the unscented one because that’s what I had on hand, but I heard the peppermint one smells amazing!). Make sure to leave some space for the pump to fit inside, otherwise it will overflow. I eyeballed the amount of soap but I’d say it was about a couple tablespoons. You’ll want to play around with the amount to match your water type.

Lastly, I added about 5 drops each of tea tree oil and lavender oil since they have antibacterial properties.

You can also add about half a teaspoon of a moisturizing oil, like sweet almond oil or vitamin E oil to keep the soap from drying your skin. If you have vitamin E capsules, you can just break open a couple of those and add that in, or some have even used olive oil or vegetable glycerin. These aren’t required, but they do add a nice soft, moisturizing feel to the soap.

Once you’e added everything, give it a good shake to combine the soap and oils with the water and that’s it, you’re good to go! Test out your pump and you should have nice, thick, foamy soap for a fraction of the price of the store bought version!

Do you use foaming hand soap? Have you ever made your own? What are your favorite scents and oil combinations?

Homemade Foaming Hand Soap
2013-03-19 09:10:37
Make your own foaming hand soap right at home with just a few simple ingredients!
Write a review
Save Recipe
Print
Ingredients
  1. Distilled, purified, or filtered water
  2. Castile soap, or your favorite natural soap (2-3 tablespoons)
  3. 5-8 drops essential oil (optional; I like lavender and tea tree)
  4. 1/2 teaspoon moisturizing oil, optional (vitamin E, almond oil, or vegetable glycerin)
  5. Empty, clean foaming soap dispenser
Instructions
  1. Fill your soap dispenser about 3/4 full with water.
  2. Add castile soap to fill the rest of the bottle, leaving some room at the top for the pump to fit.
  3. Add essential oils and moisturizing oil, if using.
  4. Cover dispenser with pump and shake well to combine the oils and soap with the water.
Notes
  1. Depending on your water type (hard/soft, etc.) you may want to play around a bit with the ratios.

title: Paleo Breakfast Muffins with Coconut Flour (Dairy-free Options)

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Yusuf’s eczema has been out of control lately, so we’ve been experimenting with different allergy-free food options until we figure out what his triggers are. We decided gluten had to go at least for the time being, but gluten-free baking is a pain, with a million different kinds of flours and binders. I just was not having it. So we decided to look into paleo options. Much easier! NomNomPaleo is now one of my favorite new blogs and these egg muffins are originally from her site.

We had an allergy test done this week and our naturopath instructed us to also keep him off dairy at least until we get the results back in two weeks. Sounds easy enough, except that this kid LOVES cheese and milk. These muffins originally call for cheddar cheese (Yusuf’s favorite!) but I had to take that out this time and instead use some other add-ins to give the muffins some flavor and substance. There’s also some yogurt, which I think is mostly there for the moisture content, so I replaced it with almond milk and they turned out fine.

I literally opened the fridge and grabbed whatever I could find to add to these muffins. I ended up with a handful of baby spinach, a small carrot, and about 1/3 cup of leftover finely diced onion. I also decided to improvise last minute by adding in some spices for an extra hint of flavor.

Oh and I also got to test out my brand new silicone muffin pan, which I’m totally in love with! It made clean up a snap and the muffins popped right out without any sticking at all. Washing it was super easy too. If you make muffins a lot, I highly recommend this 100% silicone muffin pan, if only to save your sanity! 😉

What I love about paleo baking, as opposed to gluten-free baking, is that there’s usually just a couple of flours to keep stocked in your kitchen. What I have on hand now is coconut flour from Tropical Traditions – this flour is amazing and smells just heavenly! So I’ve been gravitating towards recipes that use this since I don’t have almond flour right now (the other common paleo flour).

These muffins are so easy to make and come out so soft and tender, yet hold their shape really well and barely leave any crumbs (great for an active toddler!). The added vegetables and spices give them an extra bit of nutrition and round out the flavor really well. Even the hubby, who’s not a big egg fan at all, said he could eat these everyday. That’s a huge win in my book!

Paleo Breakfast Muffins with Coconut Flour
2013-03-17 01:35:36
Yields 6
A breakfast egg muffin made with coconut flour and baby spinach, carrots, and onions.
Write a review
Save Recipe
Print
Ingredients
  1. 4 eggs
  2. 2 tbsp full fat yogurt (or 1 1/2 tablespoons almond milk if dairy-free)
  3. 3 tablespoons coconut flour
  4. 1/4 teaspoon baking powder
  5. 1/3 cup baby spinach, finely chopped
  6. 1 small carrot, shredded
  7. 1/3 cup onion, finely diced
  8. 1/2 cup of shredded Cheddar cheese (optional, omit if dairy-free)
  9. Dash of sea salt (use more if omitting cheese)
  10. Dash of black pepper
  11. 1/4 teaspoon garlic powder
  12. 1/4 teaspoon cumin powder
Instructions
  1. Preheat oven to 375 degrees and grease a 6-cup muffin pan with melted coconut oil.
  2. Place eggs, yogurt (or almond milk), and salt into medium bowl and whisk together until blended.
  3. Sift the coconut flour and baking powder into batter and mix until smooth.
  4. Add pepper, garlic powder, and cumin and mix until blended.
  5. Add the baby spinach, carrot, onion, and cheese (if using), and continue to stir until it's all well distributed.
  6. Divide batter evenly into muffin pan and bake for 20 minutes.
  7. Allow muffins to cool on a rack for 10 minutes.
Notes
  1. When adding coconut flour to egg mixture, the flour tends become lumpy, which is why it's best to sift it into the batter.
  2. The original recipe calls for Greek yogurt, but I've used regular yogurt without a problem. Just make sure it's full-fat.
By Sarah @ Nature's Nurture

title: Natural Pregnancy: Morning Sickness Remedies

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
This post is part 1 of 5 in the series Natural Pregnancy

If you’ve ever been pregnant, I think you can agree with me when I say that I don’t know why they call it morning sickness. If it were up to me, it would be called all-day sickness, am I right? But whatever you call it, it’s still the same set of symptoms: headaches, nausea, vomiting, indigestion, and just an all around yucky feeling.

Around 3 out of 4 women will experience nausea during the first trimester of pregnancy and about half of those will start to feel relief at around 14 weeks. Raise your hand if you’re one of the “3 out of 4 women!” Yeah, thought so. I still haven’t met that 4th woman, but apparently she exists somewhere…

During my first pregnancy, I was a miserable, nauseous mess for the first trimester, and my family can vouch for that! I spent the whole time on the couch, and ate nothing but bagels, bananas, and banana milk shakes (the 3 B’s?). Thankfully, there was barely any vomiting involved, but looking back, I think that probably would’ve helped things a bit.

This time around, I knew I had to do things differently. The second I found out I was pregnant (and before morning sickness started setting in), I did loads of research on all the best ways to treat those nasty symptoms so I could try to stop them in their tracks. However, my morning sickness this time wasn’t just from nausea. No, this time, I had a lingering indigestion feeling for literally 3 months straight! No matter how much or how little I ate, or the time of day I had my meals, I always felt like my last bite was always stuck at the top of my throat. Such a terrible feeling that I was not prepared for!

Now that I’m half through this pregnancy, and way over the morning sickness hump (good riddance!), I thought I’d share a few of the things that I did this time around to try and keep myself healthy and sane for those first few months. 

Top 5 Natural Morning Sickness Remedies

  1. Lemon Water – Everyday started (and still does!) with a glass of room temperature water with a quarter lemon wedge squeezed into it. This is the first thing I had in the morning before eating or drinking anything else – not necessarily the whole thing all at once, but I took at least a few sips on an empty stomach before eating my banana. I also wrote about the health benefits of lemon water in the morning a few months ago.
  2. Ginger – Ginger tea is great at curbing nausea and settling an upset stomach. You can either use ginger tea bags or make your own tea at home by slicing some ginger root and adding it to boiling water, allowing it to boil for about 5 minutes. Then, cool and strain, then add some raw honey to taste. I also love the chewable ginger candies from GinGins. They’re great for fast relief and they taste great! If you’re into the whole “ginger ale and crackers” routine like I sometimes do, make sure you buy organic crackers with a short list of ingredients, and an all natural ginger ale like Blue Sky Ginger Ale. You can also try this yummy looking recipe for Ginger Lemon Orangeade from Kids In the Kitchen!
  3. Papaya Enzymes – This was a new one for me, but with the unbelievable indigestion I was experiencing, I’m so glad I found out about this! Taking papaya enzyme tablets before or after meals helps your stomach produce digestive enzymes to aid in digestion. These tablets are chewable and actually taste pretty yummy. You can also try eating half a grapefruit before your meals, which will do the same thing, but I’m not a big grapefruit fan. 🙁
  4. Peppermint – Peppermint has antispasmodic properties that help relieve the indigestion that comes along with nausea. A nice cup of peppermint tea can work wonders. My favorite way to use peppermint is by putting a few drops of [amazon_link id=”B00028MKRQ” target=”_blank” ]peppermint essential oil[/amazon_link] on a cotton ball and sniffing it for fairly fast nausea relief. You can also massage a few drops right onto your temples to help get rid of headaches.
  5. Vitamin B6 – No one knows exactly why, but vitamin B6 has been shown to effectively ease the nausea associated with pregnancy. Most prenatal vitamins don’t contain enough of this important vitamin, so you can either supplement with a B6 tablet or try to get it through food sources. I’m not big on supplements unless they’re absolutely necessary, so I make sure my diet includes lots of B6-rich foods like beans, nuts, bananas, and avocado.

BONUS: A good, whole-foods based Prenatal Vitamin

I can’t stress enough the importance of a good prenatal vitamin. The one I took during my first pregnancy was absolutely awful and had me feeling terrible no matter when or how I took it. I eventually stopped taking it and tried my very best to get the most out of my diet. This time, I consulted some of my natural mamma friends and have been so please with their recommendation of the [amazon_link id=”B00115BJ30″ target=”_blank” ]Rainbow Light Prenatal One[/amazon_link] vitamins. It’s just one tablet taken with or between meals, and goes down easily without making me queasy afterwards. If your prenatal vitamin is too harsh (probably because of high iron content), try taking it at night before going to sleep.

 

More Helpful Tips

Along with the remedies discussed above, there are some other tips that should be followed to ensure that you’re not making your morning sickness even worse. Following these tips along with the other remedies are vital to having a healthier pregnancy and maintaining some bout of sanity through that difficult first trimester.

  • Keep some snacks near your bed so you can eat something before getting up in the morning. Then get up slowly about 20 minutes later.
  • Don’t put off breakfast! The hungrier you get, the more intense your nausea.
  • Eat smaller, more frequent meals to maintain blood sugar levels. High protein foods are best for easing nausea.
  • Drink liquids between meals, not during. You don’t want to dilute the hydrochloric acid in your stomach, which eases digestion.
  • Avoid sugar, spicy foods, and greasy foods.
  • Some women have found relief from acupressure wrist bands, though I haven’t tried them myself.
  • Get some fresh air. It may take a little effort to actually get up, but once you’re outside in the sun, it’s totally worth it!
  • Make sure to get some rest! Try to take a nap (or at least lay down and put your feet up) everyday.
  • Stay hydrated! Make sure you’re constantly drinking water throughout the day. Coconut water is also very healthy and soothing for the stomach. Avoid caffeinated drinks and sodas which can be dehydrating and affect the body’s ability to absorb certain vitamins and minerals.

More Resources

All Natural Arsenal for Morning Sickness – Little House Living
Tips for Surviving Morning Sickness – Super Mommy
Natural Remedies for Morning Sickness – Accidentally Green

What are your best tips to help ease the symptoms of morning sickness? What hasn’t worked for you at all? What things would you add to this list?

title: Preggers Maternity Support Products {Review}

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
When I was pregnant the first time around, there was one thing that I’ve always regretted not looking into at the time: compression hosiery and belly support bands. Thankfully, I didn’t get the achy, swollen feet and legs that plague most pregnant mommas usually by the third trimester; but what I did experience was a feeling that my belly was just too, well… heavy!

I would catch myself grabbing my belly from the bottom and “lifting” it up to relieve the pressure and strain on my back. And after I’d had my son, I was still longing for some type of support garment that would lift and tighten the belly area to aid in post-partum recovery and healing. I tried a few different items for post-partum support but they all fell short for one reason or another.

Since then, I vowed that when I became pregnant the next time, I’d make sure to find a great product that would help with both maternity support *and* post-partum support. And by the grace of God, we are of course expecting our second baby this summer, and my belly has officially started to become more “bun in the oven” -like. 🙂

Luckily, I was contacted by the company Preggers, which makes and sells a whole line of maternity compression hosiery and support garments! Their products are “developed by future moms for future moms” and include everything from pantyhose and tights, to leggings and belly support bands. Their prices are very affordable, which is so important for a stay-at-home momma on a budget. 🙂 All of their products are super-soft and breathable and come in a variety of fun, stylish colors to match any wardrobe!

What does gradient compression hosiery do?
Support Hose or graduated compression has often been recommended for use during pregnancy to help energize tired, achy legs and to help reduce and prevent swelling. True gradient compression hosiery delivers a controlled amount of pressure greatest at the ankle and gradually decreases towards the top of the stocking promoting better blood flow to help energize tired legs and feet, improve circulation, and assist in the prevention of swelling. They are also ideal for individuals required to sit or stand for long periods of time.

Preggers Maternity Support Review

I knew exactly which product I wanted to try and was sent one Maternity Support Band for review. When I opened the (super cute) box and actually felt the support band, I was unbelievably surprised with just how soft and stretchy it was! Truly unlike any of the other products I’d tried. It’s so soft, that I really was skeptical about just how supportive it would actually be. Another great plus is that this band is completely seamless – so no more annoying seam marks digging into our already sensitive skin.

The support band came just in time because I’ve just recently been catching myself doing the old “belly lift” whenever I get up from sitting down. So I immediately slipped on the band and adjusted it to the right position. I was expecting a workout while putting it on, but it was actually quite easy to pull it up. For some reason, it seems a little longer than the one in the pictures on their website, so I had to fold down the top part a little and it was fine. Even with it folded down, the band stayed put all day long. The bottom didn’t ride up and the top didn’t unfold or start rolling up or down or anything.

I was on my feet for much of the first day of wearing the support band and by the end of the day, I actually felt so much better than I had in a while. My back seemed to be doing better and I didn’t feel completely wiped out – exhausted yes, but not that unbelievable fatigue that can take over after a long day. 

This band is so soft, honestly, I can’t even tell that I have it on. It’s so soft, fits so snug against my skin, and lays completely flat underneath clothing so there’s no bulky material showing through. I will definitely continue wearing this throughout the rest of my pregnancy, and into post-partum as well! It’s important to note that this band is made specifically to be worn underneath clothing, and *not* over clothing to help it stay up (ie: to keep your now too-small jeans in place).

Also, it’s very important to use their sizing chart to make sure you get the correct size. According to their chart (which uses your pre-preggo size), I’m a size Small. I was so tempted to order a Medium, since I’ve never been a size Small in anything my entire life. But I went with my gut and followed their chart exactly, and thankfully so – it’s the perfect size. 

If you’re pregnant or have a loved on who is pregnant, I would totally recommend you check out some of the compression products that Preggers has to offer. Whether it’s panty hose, tights, leggings, or a support band, you’re bound to find something to help ease the pain and pressure on the back and legs that comes with pregnancy. Their products are very affordable and made in the USA!

Where to Buy Preggers Maternity Support Products

You can purchase Preggers products right on their website where they offer worldwide shipping. They also have a 100% satisfaction guarantee – so within 45 days, you can return your product for a full refund (if unopened) or an exchange (if worn/opened).
