title: Why I Love Dr. Bronner’s Castile Soap!

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
It’s no secret that one of my absolute favorite green cleaning products is Dr. Bronner’s castile soap. I use it in everything from my homemade floor cleaner, to my homemade laundry detergent (both liquid and powdered version), and even as a body wash and hand soap! But besides the many uses I’ve found for this amazing soap, there are other reasons that this cleaner is at the very top of my green cleaning arsenal of products.

Castile soap is a vegetable-based soap, as opposed to being made from animal fats, and is one of the most environmentally-friendly soaps no the market today – especially since it’s an actual soap, and not a harsh detergent in disguise like most other “soaps.” It’s free of harsh, toxic chemicals and is completely biodegradable, meaning it won’t harm the waste stream!

Dr. Bronner’s is my absolute favorite brand of castile soap because it’s made from 100% certified fair trade and organic ingredients like coconut, olive, and hemp oils, as well as essential oils. I use both the liquid and bar forms for different purposes, and I love experimenting with all the lovely scents they have ([amazon_link id=”B001211AR8″ target=”_blank” ]almond[/amazon_link]and[amazon_link id=”B00120VWJ0″ target=”_blank” ]peppermint[/amazon_link] are my favorite!); but my go-to bottle is the [amazon_link id=”B000HK1OOY” target=”_blank” ]Baby Mild Unscented[/amazon_link] since I can usually add my own scents with essential oils.

The bottles claim “18-in-1 Uses” with everything from body wash to toothpaste, but I’ve got my own list of my absolute favorite ways to use this truly magical soap in my home:

  1. Laundry Detergent – The bottle says to use it straight (1/3 to 1/4 cup) in your dispenser, but if you make your own at home, you can stretch it even further! Check out both my liquid detergent and powder detergent recipes to see which one works best for you!
  2. Shampoo – Before I started using baking soda and vinegar to wash my hair and on days that I feel like I just need a good lather, I pour a small amount of soap into my palm, rub my hands together to work up a lather, then apply to my hair and shampoo as normal. For the hubby, I mix up a larger batch of 1 part soap to 3 parts water and store it in a squeeze bottle. Depending on your hair type, this may or may not work with your hair, so try it out and see.
  3. Body Wash – I just put a little soap directly on my wet wash cloth, lather up, then rinse. I also like to keep a larger batch in a squeeze bottle with 2 parts soap and 1 part water for guests who may be staying over.
  4. Veggie Wash – I keep a spray bottle next to my sink filled with 2 cups of water and 1 tablespoon of soap. When I’m just washing a couple pieces of fruits or vegetables, I spray it on, scrub them with my hands, then rinse.
  5. Shaving Cream – I haven’t bought shaving cream in years and usually just use whatever body wash I have in the shower. Now I just use a couple drops of castile soap to create a nice, gentle lather before shaving. It leaves your skin so silky smooth!

Looking for more great ways to use castile soap? I’m blogging over at Healthy Planet today about 10 ways to use castile soap! Click the link below to get the rest of the list!

10 Ways to Use Castile Soap

And for even more on the wonders of castile soap, check out my buddy Sara’s (from My Merry Messy Life) great post on the Magic and Reality of Dr. Bronner’s Castile Soap.

title: OraMD Natural Toothpaste {Review & Giveaway} – 3 Winners!

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Toothpaste is one area that I’ve really struggled with when it comes to finding a natural, homemade alternative to the chemical-filled versions found in the store. I’ve tried homemade versions before but they always fell short. We used them for a period of time and then just gave up after a while. So we always resort back to a natural brand, but even the “natural” brands at the health food store that don’t contain fluoride, still contain other questionable ingredients like sodium lauryl sulfate, which may contribute to canker sores, and glycerin, which coats the teeth and prevents mineral absorption.

I had just about given up on a truly natural toothpaste and began convincing myself that if I really wanted to use something natural, I’d have to suck it up and just deal with the subpar homemade versions we’ve made in the past.

 

That is until I started hearing the online buzz about a new product called OraMD. OraMD, created by Trusted Health Products, is an all-natural liquid toothpaste, mouthwash, and breath freshener which claims to be a “potent bacteria fighter.” It’s anti-bacterial, anti-microbial, anti-fungal and anti-inflammatory. It’s made from a specific formulation of peppermint, spearmint, and almond botanical oils that helps kill 22 types of oral bacteria. Hmm, sounded too good to be true, so I just had to contact them and see if I can try the product for myself.

OraMD Natural Toothpaste Review

I was sent one 15mL bottle of OraMD to try. I must say, I was initially a bit skeptical of this small bottle of pure liquid. I’m so used to a paste or a gel-type product when I think of toothpaste, so I kind of just put the bottle in my bathroom mirror and it sat there for quite some time before I finally decided to give it a try.

Before I used it I read all the directions and information, and even after all that, I can’t say I was fully prepared for the super invigorating experience I felt the first time I tried it! Initially, I didn’t like it… at all. It was way too strong, even though I’d used the minimum recommended 2 drops on my toothbrush. But as they say on their website and I later learned, the first time is kind of a shock for your mouth and the more you use it, the more you get used to it. By the second or third brushing, it wasn’t quite so bad – still strong, but more bearable.

Once I got over the super strong taste factor, I realized that I kind of liked this new way of caring for my teeth. It’s really so simple – just a couple drops on your toothbrush and brush as normal. To use as a mouthwash, just add a few drops to an ounce of water and gargle with it. And as a breath freshener and to kill bacteria throughout the day, a few drops on the tip of the tongue to coat the gum line and teeth. 

Honestly, I focused mostly on the toothbrushing part, occasionally on the mouthwash part, and only a few times on the breath freshener part just to try it. I really like brushing my teeth with this new liquid version now. My mouth feels clean and fresh even hours after brushing, my teeth feel super smooth and silky, and when I’m finished brushing, the entire bathroom has a fresh, minty scent! 

Note: OraMD contains essential oil of almond, so those with nut allergies should take precaution. Also, OraMD is safe for children 3 and up, but should not be used by pregnant or breastfeeding women due to the high potency of the essential oils.

Other Awesome Benefits of OraMD

  • Comes in a small, convenient bottle that can be carried anywhere – pocket, purse, carry-on luggage, etc.
  • Has a one year 100% money-back guarantee.
  • Saves money over conventional toothpastes.
  • Fluoride-free, alcohol-free, SLS-free, GMO-free, and made in the USA.
  • Safe for all dental work including braces, fillings, crowns, dentures, etc.

I’m really quite impressed with this product, especially since I was initially so skeptical about its effectiveness. I won’t know for sure how well it works until the next time I’m at the dentist, but personally I feel like my mouth is much cleaner and healthier. If you’re looking for a truly all-natural toothpaste and mouthwash combo and you’re tired of roaming the aisles or subjecting yourself to more homemade concoctions, I say give OraMD a try – if you don’t like it, you can send it back; you really have nothing to lose.

And while you’re at it, why not swing by and show OraMD some love at the following links?

Website | Facebook | Twitter

How to Try OraMD Toothpaste

The manufacturer is willing to offer Nature’s Nurture readers one FREE bottle to try! They said they would love to have our readers try out OraMD and agreed to send one bottle FREE if our readers would pay a minimal shipping and handling charge ($5.97).  They also agreed to include 2 eye-opening reports called 1) “The 6 Hidden Dangers In Toothpaste” and 2) “Why The FDA Requires A Warning Label On Your Toothpaste.”  That’s a total value of over $40.00.  Click here to get your FREE bottle and FREE reports now.

How to Win OraMD Toothpaste

In addition to the very generous offer above, OraMD is also offering three (3) Nature’s Nurture readers a chance to win their very own full size bottle of OraMD toothpaste and mouthwash! title: Elderberry Life {Review & Sponsor Spotlight} #SustainableSpring

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
I am so excited to bring you today’s review products and the sponsor of the Spring Into Sustainability giveaway hop, which starts on March 20, 2013! So much, that I’m just going to get right to it!

Have you heard of the amazing health benefits of elderberry? Elderberries are a rich, purple berry herb which come from the elder tree, and have been used for many years for their wonderful immune-boosting properties. This amazing berry can literally stop a cold or flu in its tracks and is great for bacterial and viral infections, as well as coughs and sore throat. They’re a great antioxidant and have even been shown to lower cholesterol and improve heart health!

I’ve been wanting to try my hand at making elderberry syrup for a long time now, but just haven’t gotten around to it. So I was very excited when the nice folks over at Elderberry Life contacted me and asked me to review some of their elderberry products!

Elderberry Life is a wonderful company with a passion to do just one thing – spread the good news about elderberries. Pure and simple. 🙂 They grow and harvest their berries on a privately owned farm in Missouri, using natural and sustainable farming practices, and produce all sorts of lovely healing products from those berries.

Did you know that only 10% of all elderberry products consumed in the US are actually grown in the US? The other 90% are imported from Europe!

Elderberry Life Review

Elderberry Life products are pure and natural, and include everything from juices and cordials, to jam and jelly. For this review, I was sent a very generous sampling of their products which included Elderberry Juice, Blackberry Elderberry Juice, Elderberry Peach Juice, Elderberry Aid,  Elderberry Herbal Cordial, Elderberry Jam and Elderberry Jelly.

Having never actually tried elderberry before, I didn’t know what to expect; but these products are absolutely delicious! My husband and son are especially fond of the jam and jelly, which go great on an English muffin and make a mean peanut butter and jelly sandwich! In Mr. Nurture’s words, elderberries have such a “wild and bright taste.” The man was eating the jam straight out of the jar, I kid you not! 😉
Note: The jam and jelly are lightly sweetened with pure cane sugar.

The juices are also very tasty and each have their own distinct flavors. You’re supposed to take 1-3 tablespoons (about 1 oz.) a day during the cold and flu season. The juice was a bit strong on its own, but then we taste tested them by adding a couple tablespoons to a glass of some sparkling water we had in the fridge. Yum! Absolutely delicious and refreshing! The Herbal Cordial had an extra special taste because of the addition of cinnamon, cloves, and honey, which also makes it great for a sore throat or flu remedy.

What do I love most about Elderberry Life products (besides their deliciousness, of course)? All their products are packaged in recyclable glass jars and bottles! So you can either repurpose them or toss them in the recycle bin. No nasty plastics – yay! 🙂

Where to Buy Elderberry Life Products

If you live in the North Carolina or Tennessee area, you may be able to purchase these products locally from their retail outlets. Otherwise, you may purchase them online through their website.

Their prices are very reasonable and they even sell some of their products in cases so you can save even more. Best of all, they offer FREE SHIPPING on orders over $100! Use coupon code: “I LOVE ELDERBERRY”.

These are truly great products that provide a delicious way to keep your immune system in tip-top shape all year long!

Give them a try and be sure to follow Elderberry Life for recipes, tips, and promotions!

The contest will run for 10 days and will be open to US residents only. title: Homemade Stovetop Popcorn (And Seasoning Ideas!)

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
There’s nothing like a big bowl of salty, buttery popcorn to dig into while you curl up on the couch and watch a movie, is there? I just love the smell, the taste, the texture, and the yummy buttery goodness! What I don’t love, however, is nasty chemicals leeching into my food, and if you’re making microwave popcorn at home, that’s exactly what you’re getting!

What’s In Microwave Popcorn?

Image courtesy Cox Health and Fitness

There’s a chemical coating on microwave popcorn bags that breaks down when heated and turns into perfluorooctanoic (PFOA), a substance the FDA has identified as “a likely carcinogen.” And if that wasn’t enough to scare you off from eating microwave popcorn forever, that fake butter flavoring is also something to be weary of. Diacetyl, an FDA-approved chemical, is actually what’s responsible for that butter flavor and smell. It’s so toxic that scores of popcorn factory workers have developed what’s referred to as “popcorn lung” – a chronic and often fatal lung condition.

So what’s a popcorn lover to do? Well, like everything else here on Nature’s Nurture, we’re going to make our own, of course! Now before we go putting some popcorn kernels into a brown paper bag and throwing it into the microwave (which is totally possible), let’s just forget that the microwave exists. I do have a microwave and I do use it from time to time, but it’s something that we really try to keep to a bare minimum in our house (and will hopefully get rid of one day!). I really believe microwaves are a bad idea not only for our health, but also for the nutritional content of our food.

How to Make Stovetop Popcorn

Since I don’t have an air popper, and I’m in no need for an extra kitchen gadget taking up valuable space on my counters or cabinets, I just make popcorn on the stovetop – the old fashioned way. It’s really quite simple, doesn’t take much time at all, and if you’ve got kids at home, it’s a real treat to watch the little kernels pop, pop, pop – especially if your pots have glass lids! 🙂

Here’s the basic, simple “recipe” for making homemade popcorn on the stovetop. If you’re looking for different ways to season your popcorn (butter is just the beginning!), check the list at the end of this post for some yummy and tasty ideas!

All you need is some oil (I use expeller-pressed coconut oil from Tropical Traditions), popcorn, and salt. You could use whatever oil you have on hand, but I tend to stay away from vegetable oils since they become oxidized when exposed to heat. Coconut oil is very heat stable and the expeller-pressed variety has no coconut taste or smell.

Heat your oil in a large heavy-bottom pot/pan (I use stainless steel). Then add the popcorn and salt, stir around a bit, and cover the pan with a lid, leaving some space for steam to escape.

 

 

 

 

After a few minutes, you’ll hear the kernels start to pop! Give the pan a gentle shake a few times to move the kernels around so they don’t burn. Note: Don’t remove the cover like I did – that was just for a quick photo-op. Otherwise, you’ll literally have projectile popcorn all over the place!

Once the popping comes to a stop (or several seconds between pops), immediately remove the pan from the heat and remove the lid. Voila! You’ve just made popcorn!

Now dump the popcorn into a large bowl and season however you would like. You could drizzle with a few tablespoons of melted butter and add more salt to taste for a classic bowl of butter popcorn. Or you can get creative and try some of the yummy ideas in the list below! My favorite go-to seasoning is some olive oil and grated parmesan cheese!

How do you make your popcorn? What are your favorite toppings and seasoning ideas?

 

Homemade Stovetop Popcorn
2013-02-25 15:35:32
Write a review
Save Recipe
Print
Ingredients
  1. 2-3 tablespoons oil – I use expeller-pressed coconut oil.
  2. ½ cup popcorn
  3. ½ teaspoon salt (optional)
  4. Large heavy-bottom pan with a lid – I use stainless steel.
  5. Optional toppings (see list for ideas)
Instructions
  1. Heat oil in pan on medium heat.
  2. Add popcorn and salt and stir around to coat all kernels.
  3. Cover pan with lid, leaving some space for steam to escape (otherwise, you’ll have soggy popcorn).
  4. Within a few minutes, you’ll start to hear the kernels pop. Give the pan a gentle shake back and forth a couple times to move kernels around (so they don’t burn).
  5. Once popping comes to a stop (several seconds between pops), immediately remove pan from heat.
  6. Remove lid, pour popcorn into a bowl, and season to taste!
By Sarah @ Nature's Nurture
Nature's Nurture http://naturesnurtureblog.com/
Wordpress Recipe Plugin by Recipe Card

Ideas for Popcorn Seasonings

Start with a bowl of freshly popped popcorn, drizzled wither in some melted butter or olive oil (or both!) and try some of the ideas below:

  • Parmesan cheese
  • Herbs like dill, basil, parsley, etc.
  • Hot sauce (mixed with the butter first)
  • Garlic sautéed in butter
  • Salt and vinegar
  • Lemon pepper
  • Chili powder
  • Cumin powder
  • Paprika

For more ideas, including gourmet toppings like vanilla, caramel bake, cheese, and kettle corn, check out TipNut.com‘s awesome list!

title: Coconut Oil for Heart Health?

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Image courtesy of Pixomar / FreeDigitalPhotos.net

February is Heart Health Month so I’ve been focusing on heart health over at the Healthy Planet blog. Today I decided to look into the heart health benefits of my absolute favorite oil to use in the kitchen – coconut oil! If you’ve kept up with mainstream medical opinion over the past few decades, it’s easy to understand why I put a question mark in the title of this post.

You see, since the ’50s and ’60s, coconut oil has received some pretty bad press. Researchers and medical professionals discovered the negative health effects of saturated fats and because coconut oil is very high in saturated fats, of course it got lumped in with the rest of the unhealthy fats out there. Unfortunately, what researchers failed to mention was that not all saturated fats are created equal; the saturated fats in coconut oil are naturally occurring, not man-made like other vegetable oils. That makes a huge difference!

But that’s not all. Another major discrepancy in the research on coconut oil over the years has to do with the type of coconut oil that was used in these studies. Virgin coconut oil is the most natural, unprocessed form of coconut oil you can get. (My favorite source is from Tropical Traditions.) But did those researchers use virgin coconut oil in their studies? Nope, absolutely not. They used highly processed, partially hydrogenated coconut oil! And when you hydrogenate anything, you get those evil trans fats that we’re always hearing about. It’s those trans fats that we really need to stay away from, not the healthy saturated fats found in virgin coconut oil.

So now that we’ve gotten that figured out, let’s delve into why (virgin) coconut oil is good for our hearts and overall health! Follow the link below to continue reading this post over on the Healthy Planet blog!

Heart Health Benefits of Coconut Oil

content:
This guest post is from Krystyna at Spring Mountain Living.

Out of all the snacks I remember from childhood, nothing calls to me like good, old-fashioned Rice Crispy Treats. I assumed I would have to say farewell to this long-time favorite, but after some experimenting in the kitchen, I found that I was wrong. Thank goodness!

Healthy Rice Crispy Treats
Author: Krystyna @ Spring Mountain Living
Ingredients
  • 1 1/3 cup tahini
  • 2 teaspoon vanilla extract
  • 8 cup puffed rice
  • ¾ cup honey
  • ½ cup ground flax
  • Dash of sea salt
Instructions
  1. Mix tahini, honey, vanilla & salt in a pot, stirring until mixture combines.
  2. Stir ground flax into mixture.
  3. Add puffed rice ½ to 1 scoop at a time while continuing to stir.
  4. When finished, press mixture into a greased pan. You will need to press and mold the mixture to the pan.
  5. Let sit for one or more hours in a cool place.
  6. Cut into squares and enjoy!
3.2.1226

After you’ve given this recipe a go, try switching things up to make a different desert.  Try sandwiching a layer of peanut butter in the middle of this delish desert!  Or add some chocolate chips to the top and warm in the oven for a few minutes to melt and create a yummy candy bar treat!

If you can’t find puffed rice, try using crispy rice instead.  The texture and taste may be slightly different, depending on brands, but they are both capable of satisfying those cravings from your inner child.

What’s your favorite comfort food from childhood?

title: Natural Sources of Vitamin D

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Image courtesy of bulldogza / FreeDigitalPhotos.net

Since our family lives up in Canada where the winters are pretty long, there’s always the concern over how much Vitamin D we’re getting into our bodies. But even if you don’t live up north, during the winter months, when the sun is at its lowest point, it’s difficult for most of us to receive an adequate amount of Vitamin D. Since I like to stay away from supplements as much as possible, I try to rely mostly on natural food sources of Vitamin D for my family.

Of course hands down, the powerful sun is by far the best natural source for those healthy UV rays (which our bodies actually convert to Vitamin D all on its own!), but when that doesn’t work out, there are other things we can do to increase our Vitamin D intake and keep our bodies healthy and functioning properly.

My favorites are healthy fish like salmon and tuna, which boast anywhere between a whopping 200-900 IU per serving! Another impressive sources, and something I’ve yet to try, is cod liver oil which contains over 1,300 IU in just one tablespoon! But I’m still doing more research on this supplement, so I can’t say much for it right now.

Read more on the recommended daily value of vitamin D, along with more sources for vitamin D in this week’s post for Healthy Planet (click link below)!

 

Natural Sources for Vitamin D

title: How to Make Homemade Mayo

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Mayonnaise is one of those things you either love or hate. I happen to really enjoy a light slather of mayo on my sandwiches, and tuna salad just wouldn’t be the same without it. But unfortunately, once we purged our fridge and pantry of everything that contained unpronounceable ingredients and artificial preservatives and flavors, mayo was one of the things that had to go.

The good news is that making your own homemade mayo is pretty simple and straightforward. We’ve come a long way from the days of our grandmothers who used to whisk their mayo by hand for what felt like hours on end. If you’ve got a blender, food processor, or an emersion blender, you’re good to go!

Your basic mayo includes eggs, oil, an acid, and some spices. The most important thing to note is that all of your ingredients must be at room temperature! This is key to getting a nice emulsion, otherwise you can “break” your mayo and everything separates into an oily, liquid mess.

I’ll give you just the basic, simple recipe for mayo and I’ve also included a list at the end with all sorts of yummy additions to help you experiment with different flavors. Every time I’ve made mayo, it’s come out a little different because of what I’ve added or left out. So I definitely recommend trying your hand at a few variations to see what best suits your tastes!

My first batch. No pepper. So thick and creamy!

The super easy ingredient list is just 1 cup oil, 1 egg, 1 tablespoon lemon juice, 1 teaspoon mustard powder, 1/2 teaspoon salt, and 1/4 teaspoon pepper (use white pepper if you don’t want black specks in your mayo).

You’ll put all the ingredients, except the oil, into your blender and blend for about one minute, until it’s light and frothy.

Then, turn the blender back on, and remove the fill cap (the little insert in the lid). With the blender on, s-l-o-w-l-y begin pouring the oil into the blender. A very fine, thin stream is what we’re aiming for here. Any faster and your emulsion will break (which can be fixed, but is annoying).

But don’t worry, it sounds harder than it is. Just use a measuring cup with a spout to help you control your oil stream. This step should take about a minute, probably longer since you might have to stop to scrape down the sides of the blender a couple times. You may or may not use the full cup of oil (I usually use between 3/4 and 1 cup), so stop to check your mayo at about 3/4 cup. If it’s to your liking, you’re good to go!

Transfer your mayo to a glass jar and store in the fridge for up to one week. I’ve heard of others extending the life of their mayo by fermenting it on the counter for a few hours with some whey, but I personally haven’t tried that yet. If you try it, I’d love to hear your thoughts!

 

Homemade Mayo
2013-09-17 19:10:54
Making this staple condiment is much easier than you might think! A few simple ingredients is all it takes to have fresh, delicious homemade mayo!
Write a review
Save Recipe
Print
Ingredients
  1. 1 egg, organic (preferably farm-fresh)
  2. 1 tablespoon lemon juice
  3. 1 teaspoon mustard powder
  4. 1/2 teaspoon salt
  5. 1/4 teaspoon pepper
  6. 1 cup oil
Instructions
  1. Add egg, lemon juice, mustard, salt and pepper to blender and blend for one minute until light and frothy.
  2. Remove fill cap and, while blender is running, slowly begin pouring oil into blender in a very thin stream. This step should take at least a minute, but you may need to stop and scrape down sides of blender.
  3. Once all oil is incorporated, turn off blender and taste the mayo. If it's missing something, stir it in at this time. Otherwise, transfer to a glass container and store in fridge up to one week.
By Sarah UmmYusuf
Nature's Nurture http://naturesnurtureblog.com/
Wordpress Recipe Plugin by Recipe Card
3.1.09

 

What Kind of Oil to Use?

My go-to oil is extra-light olive oil – if you use extra-virgin, your mayo will have a very strong olive oil flavor and won’t taste much like mayo at all. I don’t use canola oil or any other vegetable oils at all in our kitchen, but if you keep those on hand, you can definitely use those. Some other great oils to use include grapeseed oil, sunflower oil, macadamia nut oil, and even a combination of coconut oil and any of the other oils mentioned. Each one will bring a different flavor and depth to your mayo, so experiment away!

What About the Raw Eggs?

Yes, there are raw eggs in your homemade mayo, and yes, raw eggs do carry a risk of salmonella. If you’re uncomfortable with that, then by all means, I am not here to coerce you into consuming raw eggs. But what I will say is this: if you’re using organic, preferably farm-fresh eggs from a trusted source, you’re probably on the safe side. But again, we’re all adults here and can make our own decision. 🙂

Egg-free Options

If you’ve got egg allergies in the house or are otherwise avoiding eggs, no worries – I found quite a few variations to make an egg-free version of homemade mayo!

How to Make Your Own Egg-Free Mayo – This version uses heavy cream, so if you’re dairy-free, this one is not for you.
Egg-Free Olive Oil Mayo – This interesting version uses tahini, nut milk, and xantham gum.
Eggless Mayonnaise Recipes – This is a collection of different recipes using various ingredients from yogurt and condensed milk, to tofu and soy milk.

Extra Notes

  • You can use either your blender, an emersion blender or a food processor, but I found the blender to be the easiest.
  • Remember – ALL ingredients must be at room temperature, so set out your egg and lemon on the counter for a few hours!
  • Some recipes call for just the egg yolk, giving you a more yellow-tinted mayo. I use the whole egg and have no issue with the results. It’s easier and I don’t have to find a reason to use an egg white on the spot.
  • If you ask me if this tastes like Hellman’s or Kraft or any other brand, I honestly could’t tell you. It tastes like mayo to me, and that’s why I like playing around with different spice combinations to get the flavor I’m in the mood for at the time (check the list below for ideas).
  • I’ve also heard a great tip for getting a more stable emulsion is to add a tablespoon of water, but I haven’t found the need to try it so far.
  • If your emulsion breaks, you can fix it by starting with a fresh bowl and add a tablespoon of water. Then add in the broken mixture a little at a time, whisking by hand, and your emulsion should start to form again.

Optional Add-Ins

  • Vinegar for a tart flavor
  • Sugar or honey for a sweeter mayo
  • Chili powder
  • Cayenne pepper
  • Garlic powder or minced garlic
  • Dijon mustard
  • Hot sauce

Have you made homemade mayo before? What are your favorite add-ins and spice combinations?

title: How To Tell If Your Eggs Are Good {TinyTipTues}

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Guess what? Tiny Tip Tuesday is back!! Well, sort of… I miss sharing my tiny tips with you every week, but I’m not sure if I’m ready to start up the link party again just yet. And I’m not even sure if Tiny Tip Tuesday will actually be every Tuesday either, but for now, whenever I’ve got a great tip to share with you, it’ll be posted on Tuesday for your viewing pleasure. 🙂

We just got back from visiting family down in Florida for a couple weeks, and although I thought we’d completely emptied our fridge before leaving, I was surprised to come back and find 2 lonely eggs still in their carton in my fridge door. I contemplated whether or not to throw them out, but then I remembered reading a while ago that you can actually do a quick test to see if your eggs are still good to eat.

It’s really quite simple. All you need is a bowl of cold water, and of course your eggs. Working with each egg individually, place the egg into the bowl of water.

If it sinks to the bottom, it’s still good. If it sinks but is standing on its point, it’s good but should be used soon. And if it floats to the top, then it’s no longer good and should be thrown out.

Both of my eggs sunk to the bottom but were standing on one end. So, looks like we’re having eggs for breakfast today!

For comparison, I took a new egg from the fridge to test, and it sank right to the bottom, clearly laying on its side.

So there you have it! If you’ve got some eggs you’re unsure of, don’t throw them out right away. Instead, do this quick egg test to see if they’re still good to eat! I’ve included an easy chart below for reference:

If it SINKS GOOD!
If it SINKS, but stands on its point GOOD, but use up soon!
If it FLOATS BAD!

 

Have you ever tried this egg test before? Did you actually get one that floated in the water?

title: Natural Ways to Prevent & Treat Heartburn

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Image courtesy of stopheartburn.com

We’ve all been hit by the heartburn bug at one point or another. Whether it was too much spicy food, eating too quickly, or something completely out of your hands like pregnancy heartburn, that all-too familiar feeling of burning in your throat and chest is unfortunately a fact of life for a lot of us.

But there are things we can do to both prevent the onset of heartburn, as well as treat it naturally if we’re past the point of prevention. Yes, there are all sorts of over-the-counter and prescription medications that can be taken to help relieve the symptoms, but unfortunately, those may actually be causing more harm than good!

Prevention is key, and the best way to try to stop heartburn before it starts is to completely avoid trigger foods as much as possible, and eating smaller meals. Trigger foods differ from person to person, but can include spicy foods, caffeine, and even dairy products. Check the link below for more ways to prevent heartburn.

When heartburn hits in our house, our first line of defense is some raw, unfiltered apple cider vinegar (ACV). It seems the uses for ACV are almost endless, and heartburn relief is another one to add to the list. I usually take about 2 tablespoons diluted in a small glass of water, but you can also take it straight.

Although it’s an acid, the type of acid in ACV (acetic acid) is actually a weak acid. When it mixes with a stronger acid (like the hydrochloric acid in our stomachs), the overall acidity of the stomach is reduced, bringing almost instant relief to the burning sensation brought on by heartburn.

For more natural ways to prevent and treat heartburn symptoms, please click the link below…

5 Natural Heartburn Remedies

title: 10 Unconventional Uses for Honey

author.name: Guest Blogger
author.description: This post was contributed by one of our awesome guest bloggers, sharing tips about everything simple, natural, and homemade! Be sure to check out their website and visit their social media pages!

content:
This guest post is by Krystyna of Spring Mountain Living.

When most people think of honey, they think of satisfying their sweet-tooth.  You  might be surprised to find out honey has some unconventional uses you (maybe) haven’t heard about.

  1. Wash your face with it. When I started using raw honey as a face wash, my skin issues resolved and my pores reduced in size, making me look a bit younger. Replacing your store-bought face wash with honey is a great way to save money (and your skin from chemicals).  Just be sure to use unrefined honey, or you’ll lose the benefits I mentioned through the pasteurization process.
  2. Use it as topical antibiotic cream.   Honey has natural antibacterial and antimicrobial properties that help heal skin faster and kill germs and infections.  Apply it over a cut or burn & apply a band aide for faster healing & pain relief.
  3. Put it in your hair.   It may sound like a trick, but using some watered-down honey on your hair will reduce frizziness.
  4. Make an energy drink.   Just one tablespoon of honey mixed with some water will provide a great pick-me-up in the middle of the day.  And you won’t get a caffeine crash like you would with coffe.
  5. Stockpile.  Honey never goes bad, as long as it’s stored in a sealed container.  Stock up on it without fear of expiration.
  6. Put it on your lips.  Honey really soothes my sore, chapped lips in the winter.  I just apply it directly on my lips, while trying to resist the temptation to lick, and let it work its magic.
  7. Treat colds & cure sore throats. Try Spring Mountain Living’s Cough & Cold Cure in our Healthy Holiday article.  This is our go-to remedy for sickness and sore throats in our house.  It works better than any over-the-counter or prescription cold medicine we’ve ever tried!
  8. Control odors. Did you know that honey absorbs odors?  Coat stinky feed or underarms with honey for a few minutes while bathing to illuminate or reduce offending smells.
  9. Take it to sleep. Unadulterated honey, or honey in its natural state, is high in tryptophan and potassium, both soothing for the brain & nerves.  Honey is thought to interrupt a neuro-transmitter in the brain called orexin.
  10. Treat hypoglycemia. I suffer from hypoglycemia, or low blood sugar. I have to prick my finger and test my blood regularly and if it’s below 70 mg/dL, I’m supposed to “take action” by consuming hard candy, glucose tablets, soda or milk. Between my allergies and sugar, those options don’t really sound appealing to me. But a spoonful of honey, under my tongue, helps relieve uncomfortable symptoms like headache, nausea and shakiness.

Do you use honey at your house? Share some of your uses in the comments!

title: How To Naturally Wash Your Hair

author.name: Guest Blogger
author.description: This post was contributed by one of our awesome guest bloggers, sharing tips about everything simple, natural, and homemade! Be sure to check out their website and visit their social media pages!

content:
This guest post is from Alix at Blessed In Homemaking.

How do you wash your hair? Most people use shampoo. Did you know that there is another way?

Except for the rare occasion that I shower away from home, I haven’t used shampoo or conditioner in about 3 years.

I use baking soda for shampoo, and apple cider vinegar for conditioner.
I put the baking soda in a squirt bottle and fill it with water. I use around 2 Tbsp of baking soda.
I use 1/4 C. vinegar in a jar of water. I don’t rinse out the vinegar. You can if you want, but I prefer not to. Vinegar doesn’t smell once it dries.

For extra conditioning I sometimes add an egg yolk to the vinegar (you rinse this out, of course.) Be sure to rinse with cool water, or you may find cooked egg in your hair!

These are the amounts that work for my hair, and they are a good starting place. You may need to tweak it a bit to find what works for you.

It can take your hair 2-4 weeks to detox before it starts feeling and looking good. It took mine about 2 weeks. My hair feels so good using this method, and it’s so much better for your health and your hair’s health. Store bought products are full of toxic and carcinogenic ingredients, even the “organic” or “all natural” ones.

Another plus to using this method is that (for me at least), my hair only needs to be washed every 3-5 days. It just stays so much cleaner, and doesn’t get oily like it did when I washed it with shampoo.

Do you clean your hair naturally? Are you interested in doing so?

My name is Alix. I am a stay at home wife and mother. I am an herbalist and diaper changer, a business owner and a meal maker. I love the Lord and my family. You can find me at my blog and on Facebook.

title: The Amazing Health Benefits of Coconut Oil

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Image courtesy of Pixomar / FreeDigitalPhotos.net

I’ve written about my love for coconuts and coconut oil quite extensively in the past, but what I’ve never done is really get into the technical reasons of just why coconut oil is so amazing. I use it for everything from a skin moisturizer and hair conditioner, to a cooking/baking oil and body scrub! I’m telling you, I love all things coconut, especially coconut oil.

I only use two oils in my kitchen: extra virgin olive oil for cold use (such as salads), and coconut oil for high heat cooking. Coconut oil is the only oil stable enough to withstand the heat of cooking and is therefore the healthiest oil available for this purpose. Since heating olive oil makes it susceptible to oxidative damage, it’s not a healthy oil to use for cooking.

My favorite source for coconut oil is definitely Tropical Traditions. I use their expeller-pressed coconut oil for high-heat cooking (scrambled eggs are delicious cooked in some coconut oil!), and their virgin coconut oil for all other applications including for hair, skin, smoothies, and baked goods that could use a bit of coconut flavor. I’ve also written a whole post on my favorite ways to use coconut oil during the summer!

If you haven’t discovered the magic of this oil yet, please do yourself a favor and pick up a jar soon!

And to read more on the wonderful health benefits of this amazing oil, check out my post at the link below which includes everything form bone health and heart health, to immune support and weight loss!

title: On The Home Front’s The Master Tonic

author.name: Guest Blogger
author.description: This post was contributed by one of our awesome guest bloggers, sharing tips about everything simple, natural, and homemade! Be sure to check out their website and visit their social media pages!

content:
This guest post is from Nancy at On the Home Front.

During the winter months when there is so much flu going around we try to take all precautions to stay healthy. When my son was younger he would usually be the one to catch whatever flu bug was going around. A friend of mine shared this recipe for The Master Tonic and once we started using it even my son stayed healthy! I’ve often thought it would also make a good seasoning for a Chinese dish. It is meant to be used to gargle with first and then you swallow it. If you use really hot peppers I swear you can feel the heat flowing through your blood vessels. I have shared this with several friends who now use it during the flu season as well.

I share it with you today exactly as it was shared with me. Beware when you chop fresh horseradish the fumes are quite powerful and when you chop hot peppers DO NOT rub your eyes, and be sure to wear gloves! When you gargle and swallow with this tonic I swear you can feel fire coursing through your veins!

Master Tonic: A Natural Antibiotic

Pro biotic: antiviral, anti-bacterial, anti-fungal and anti-parasitical.

Important note: As required by law, this information is provided by the right of free speech for educational purposes only, as natural or non-pharmaceutical remedies or therapies are in some nations today now often deemed illegal. We must therefore insist that if you are ill or have any disease or healthy problem that you contact a medical doctor immediately and ask their advice before trying any formulae, or suggestion given in this material.

This is a modern-day version of a recipe for an extremely powerful natural antibiotic originally used to fight infection like the Bubonic Plague that killed over a third of the world in the 1300’s. Unlike pharmaceutical antibiotics it fights both bacteria and viruses, and is effective against pathogens that have developed immunity to existing drugs.

Master Tonic Ingredients

Master Tonic:

1 part fresh chopped garlic cloves (anti-bacterial, anti-fungal, anti-viral anti-parasitical)

1 part fresh chopped white onion, hottest onions available (similar properties to garlic)

1 part fresh gated ginger root (increases circulation to the extremities)

1 part fresh grated horseradish root (increases blood flow to the head)

1 part fresh chopped Cayenne Peppers, the hottest peppers available, i.e. Habanero, African Bird, or Scotch Bonnets etc. (A great blood stimulant)

1 bottle raw, unfiltered, unbleached, non-distilled apple cider vinegar

Fill a large glass jar ¾ of the way full with equal parts of the above peeled, fresh, chopped or grated herbs.

I use a ½ gallon glass-canning jar and add a cup of each of the above ingredients. Then fill up the rest of the jar to the top with raw, unfiltered, unbleached, non-distilled apple cider vinegar.

(It should look milky) shake jar at least once a day for two weeks, and then filter the mixture through a clean piece of cotton (an old t-shirt) or cheesecloth, then bottle and label. If possible make sure all the vegetables and herbs are fresh and organically grown if possible, use dried herbs only in an emergency.

This tonic stimulates maximum blood circulation while putting the best detoxifying herbs into the blood. It strengthens the good guys (probiotic) in your system that helps define against infection that broad-spectrum pharmaceutical antibiotics kill. This formula is not just for the sniffles; it has helped to turn around the deadliest of infections.

The dosage is ½ to 1 ounce, two or three times daily (1-2 Tbsps. a time), gargle and swallow. Don’t dilute with water. For ordinary infections, a dropperful taken 5-6 times a day will deal with most conditions. It can be used during pregnancies, is safe for children (use smaller doses) and as a food is completely non-toxic. Make up plenty; it does not need refrigeration and lasts indefinitely without any special conditions.

(I believe the friend that shared this with me got it from The University of Natural Healing, Dr. Richard Schultzs’ adaption of Dr. Christopher’s’ original anti-plague tonic)

title: Immune-Boosting Fire Cider for Cold & Flu Season – UPDATE!

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Remember that immune-boosting fire cider that I posted about just over a month ago? Well, it’s been steeping for the past four weeks, and it’s ready! I kept it in my coffee/tea cabinet, so every morning as we prepared our coffee and tea, I grabbed the jar of fire cider and gave it a good shake to get everything redistributed, since it all tends to settle overnight. It’s been a bit hard waiting for it to be ready for consumption, and I’m so glad the wait is over – we are ready for business!

The original recipe can be found here:

Immune Boosting Fire Cider for Cold and Flu Season

When I opened the jar of fire cider and took a quick whiff, man it was F-I-R-E!!! But in a totally good way. I like all things spicy so it wasn’t too overwhelming. It looked so beautiful, I just couldn’t resist snapping a quick picture.

Then I carefully strained it into a bowl through a fine-mesh strainer. You’re supposed to use a cheesecloth (or similar item), but for the life of me, I just couldn’t find any of my cheesecloth pieces that are usually lying around the house! The mesh strainer worked fine and didn’t allow any of the little bits to fall through. The only challenge was trying to squeeze out as much of the liquid from the herbs and spices as possible. So I just pressed the back of a spoon into it until I could get out as much as possible. I’m sure I could’ve gotten way more out if I could find my darn cheesecloth, but alas, I made do with what I had.

I then put the herbs and spices back into the original glass jar and stored it in the fridge. From my last post, I shared that you can add those bits and pieces into stir-fries or even wrap them up into some eggrolls! I’m still waiting to see how we’ll use them this week.

The actual cider was poured into a clean glass jar, and I added some honey to sweeten it up a bit. I started with about a quarter-cup (4 tablespoons), but after tasting it I thought it needed just a bit more. So I think I added about 6 tablespoons of honey in total. I used local, unpasteurized honey for it’s added health benefits and immune-boosting properties. Once it was all stirred up, I covered the jar and it’s now stored on our counter near our morning routine station (coffee, tea, supplements, etc.).

We will be travelling this weekend, so we’re ramping up our immune-boosting regimen this week. As for this fire cider, we will take 1 tablespoon every morning and we’ll also probably splash some over our salads, rice dishes, etc. It’s very tasty, with a welcome kick!

So, have you made your batch of fire cider yet? What are you waiting for? What are your go-to immune-boosting remedies?

title: TotLogic Natural Baby Bath Products {Review & Giveaway}

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Finding truly natural bath and body products for babies and toddlers has proven to be a really tough task! It’s really important for us to use all-natural products on our bodies, and it’s even more important that the products we use on our little ones be as natural and non-toxic as possible.

We’ve tried many of the natural product lines on the market, but I’ve always come to find a few questionable ingredients on the label that I just wasn’t comfortable with using on Monkey. My rule of thumb is if at least one of the ingredients (or the product itself) scores more than a 3 rating (with a few exceptions) on the Environmental Working Group’s Skin Deep Database, then it’s a no-go.

We’ve settled on a couple of trustworthy brands that we are comfortable with, and when all else fails, we just resort back to Dr. Bronner’s baby mild castile soap. But I’m always looking for new baby bath products that are gentle on little ones’ skin, have a very light scent, and are safe for the environment. So I was super excited when I got the opportunity to try out some natural baby bath products from TotLogic!

TotLogic is a gentle, safe, and natural product line for the little ones in your family. The entire line includes shampoos, conditioners, lotions, diaper cream, and bubble bath.

  • They do not contain sulfates, parabens, phthalates, PEG or DEA.
  • They are free of artificial fragrances and colors, never tested on animals.
  • TotLogic products are Gluten, Dairy and Soy Free, and biodegradable.
  • All of the packaging is Recyclable
  • TotLogic products are perfect for the entire family and proudly made in the U.S.A.

TotLogic Bath Products Review

I was sent two products to try out on Monkey: the 2-in-1 wash and shampoo and the conditioner. We use the wash/shampoo almost every night and I absolutely love it! It has a nice, light scent that’s not overpowering at all, and it does a great job at getting him clean, without irritating his skin (he has eczema on his arms, and this wash is so gentle!). It lathers up nicely and doesn’t leave any residue when washed off (either on his skin or in the bathtub).

I was also excited to try the conditioner as well, since Monkey has this stubborn spot on the back of his head where his hair is just very dry, I think because he most often sleeps on his back. At first I felt weird using a conditioner on my 18-month old, but I just went with it and I’m so glad I did! After 2 weeks of using the conditioner on him twice a week, his hair is definitely much softer and smoother than before.

And just to change things up a little, I wanted to take TotLogic up on their claim that their products are “perfect for the entire family,” so I used both products on my own hair and I really like them. They feel very gentle, left my hair nice and clean, and without any leftover residue.

Ready to Try TotLogic Products?

I love that TotLogic products come from a company that really cares about their customers, as well as the planet. If you’re looking for safe, natural, and eco-friendly bath products for your family, TotLogic has a great line of products available right at their website. They also carry other lines including LiceLogic, BarkLogic, and BedBugLogic. Their prices are really affordable, they offer free shipping for orders over $49, and you also receive a free sample of their body lotion with your order! title: Homemade Coconut-Lavender Body Scrub

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Living up in the Great White North, we know a thing or two about winter, and more specifically, about dry, winter skin. In addition to regular moisturizing (usually with some virgin coconut oil), my favorite way to beat the rough, dry winter skin is with a good body scrub. But the store-bought stuff is way over-priced and sometimes too rough on sensitive skin, so of course you know I had to try making some at home. And you know what? It’s so easy, it’s much cheaper, and you can totally customize it to your liking!

Just start out with a basic recipe guideline (2 parts sugar/salt to 1 part oil) and customize to your heart’s content. 🙂 You can use either sugar or salt (I used a mixture of white and brown sugar), but just make sure it has small granules so it doesn’t tear at your skin. As for the oil, my favorite is virgin coconut oil (buy at Tropical Traditions or[amazon_link id=”B003B3OOPA” target=”_blank” ]Amazon[/amazon_link]) – I just love the way it smells and it’s health benefits are innumerable! Other great oils to use include olive oil, almond oil, grapeseed oil, and safflower oil.

The final touch to your homemade body scrub is the addition of your favorite essential oils – both for their scent, as well as their therapeutic properties. My go-to oil for bath products is[amazon_link id=”B00014EI26″ target=”_blank” ]lavender[/amazon_link], because it’s calming and relaxing – perfect for an at-home spa experience! Some other oils you can try include vanilla, jasmine, almond, chamomile, rosemary, and lemon, to name a few.

Once you’ve decided on your ingredients, simply mix the sugar/salt with the oil until nice and smooth. Then add your essential oils and mix well. Transfer the scrub into a glass jar with a tight-fitting lid and you’re ready for business!

When you’re ready to use your scrub, step into your bath and put on some bath gloves or loofah mitts. I absolutely adore my [amazon_link id=”B001G7PWCM” target=”_blank” ]bath gloves[/amazon_link] and never miss an opportunity to tell people about them. They’re great for exfoliating and you can just throw them in the washing machine when you need to (just don’t put them in the dryer!). Anyways, if you don’t have gloves or mitts, you can just use your hands.

  • Spoon some of your homemade body scrub into your hands (or gloves/mitts) and rub the mixture over your entire (dry) body, in a circular motion.
  • Try to always rub towards your heart – start at your feet and work up your legs; start at your hands and work up your arms, etc.
  • Once your entire body is scrubbed, rinse off very well with warm water, then pat dry.

Some Extra Tips

  • You most likely won’t need to moisturize afterwards, but if you do, coconut oil is a great moisturizer!
  • Don’t over-exfoliate! Once or twice a week is more than enough to keep your skin nice and soft. Any more and you could damage your skin.
  • Always exfoliate before you shave (NOT after!) – it helps remove dead skin and lifts the hair follicles so they’re easier to remove.

Have you ever used a body scrub before? Ever tried to make your own? What’s your favorite oil and salt/sugar combo?

Homemade Coconut-Lavender Body Scrub

Author: Sarah @ Nature’s Nurture
A gentle, exfoliating sugar scrub made with coconut oil and lavender oil for an at-home spa experience!
Ingredients
  • 1 cup sugar (I used a mix of white and brown sugar)
  • 1/2 cup extra virgin coconut oil
  • 5-7 drops lavender essential oil (optional)
Instructions
  1. Add sugar and coconut oil to a small bowl and mix until smooth.
  2. Add essential oil and mix well.
  3. Spoon mixture into glass container with tight-fitting lid.

title: Heating Water with the SunRocket Solar Kettle {Review/Sponsor Spotlight} #GetMoving2013

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
Solar energy is an area that I’ve always been intrigued with, but only recently started looking into seriously as a viable solution to the world’s energy crisis. Since Mr. Nurture and I are saving and planning to purchase a homestead in the near future, we’ve been researching more and more about alternative, renewable forms of energy. Solar cells and solar panels are very high on the list for home energy use, but what I’d never heard of before was portable solar energy – devices that harness the power of the sun to do things like cook food and heat up water when you’re camping, hiking, boating, etc.

So, when Sun Cooking US asked me to review their SunRocket Solar Kettle, I totally jumped on the opportunity! I get to try using the power of the sun to do something as simple as heating up some water?! Umm, yes please!

About Sun Cooking US

Sun Cooking is Australia’s largest retailer of solar cooking products and accessories, and they’ve just launched their new website, catering to the US market! It was started by Heather Stevens, and appreciated by her son Tasman (who gets to eat lots of yummy food out of the oven!). Heather and her well fed family spent 10 months living aboard their catamaran sailing Australia, and used their solar ovens daily. Isn’t that just awesome?!

What Is the SunRocket Solar Kettle?

Click image to enlarge

The SunRocket is an amazing way to heat and boil water using simply sunlight.

Using the latest in solar thermal technology, the SunRocket uses an evacuated tube, boosted by reflective panels to absorb solar heat. When opened it can heat water in as little as 30 minutes then when closed can keep hot for hours.  The contents only come in contact with pure clean glass making it safe and healthy to use. It holds 17 ounces of water and weighs about 2 pounds.

The SunRocket is scratch and weather resistant, compact and lightweight. It’s made from eco friendly materials under ethical working conditions. It’s great for picnics, BBQs, and outdoor events, camping, hiking, fishing, boating, etc. If you’re a prepper, it’s also a great addition to your emergency preparedness and disaster response kit, as it can also sanitize water and rehydrate foods. Planning a ski trip? The SunRocket can even melt snow into drinking water (see a video demo here)!

SunRocket Solar Kettle Review

I was so excited when this box showed up on my doorstep, and when I opened it up, it was even more interesting than I thought it would be. It really does look just like a rocket that’s ready for takeoff – I think Monkey may have thought it was a toy for him. 😉

I read the instructions and was ready to get started right away. I unscrewed the top, which was a bit hard to get off at first (only the first time though), and washed it with warm, soapy water, as instructed. I filled it up with water and was about to go outside to try it out, but decided it was a little too cloudy up here in Toronto, so I waited until the next day when the forecast was more sunny.

The thing with solar cooking is that you’re really at the mercy of the sun – if there’s no sun, there’s just no cooking. The next day was a very sunny day, so I went outside with my kettle at around 11 am, opened up the panels on the kettle, propped it up on its support handle, and placed it in direct sun, with the shadow directly behind it. I left it there for about an hour, then brought it back inside to check on the water.

I don’t know what I expected, but to say that hot water would be coming out of that thing, after I left in nearly freezing weather outside for an hour, was a bit…surprising. I poured myself a cup of tea, and amazingly, the hot water steeped my tea and I enjoyed my very first cup of solar-powered tea! 🙂 How cool is that? And not only that, but the kettle also doubles as a thermos, so it kept my water warm for another hour, when Mr. Nurture took a break from working and joined me for another cup of tea!

And according to the package insert, you can even cook simple foods in the SunRocket, like eggs, although I haven’t tried that yet.

The SunRocket is such a nifty little device and makes a great gift for the campers, hikers, boaters, or any outdoorsy types in your family. It’s even small enough to fit in your backpack!

Learn more about the great products that Sun Cooking US has to offer, as well as cooking tips, tricks, and specials:

Website | Facebook | Twitter | YouTube

Where to Buy the SunRocket Solar Kettle

The SunRocket is available for purchase online at SunCookingUS.com. It runs about $57 and can be shipped anywhere around the US.

The nice folks at Sun Cooking US have also kindly offered a special 20% off discount for all Nature’s Nurture readers from now until January 31, 2013! Just use the following discount code at checkout: SOLAR

SunCooking US will also be giving away one SunRocket in the Get Moving 2013 Giveaway Hop. Come back January 17, 2013 to enter for your chance to win!

title: Surviving the Cold & Flu Season Naturally

author.name: Sarah UmmYusuf
author.description: Sarah is a wife and mother with a passion for all things simple, natural, and homemade. Join her and thousands of others on their journey to a natural lifestyle!

content:
We’re right in the middle of the cold and flu season and that either means runny noses and sore throats (hopefully not!) or it means lots of preventive measures being taken to make sure we don’t come down with anything this season. Either way, one thing is for sure: natural remedies and treatments are key to making it through this time of year, safe and sound.

I’ve been posting a lot about the natural ways we try to boost our immunity, as well as some natural remedies for when a cold does strike, so I figured I’d share them with you here, so we have a “one-stop shop” for the natural ways we choose to tackle the cold and flu season.

Natural Ways to Prevent and Treat the Common Cold – What’s working for us is mainly increasing our intake of healthy, immune-boosting foods with high levels of vitamin C and zinc, like oranges, broccoli, and spinach. We’re also taking local, raw honey in our tea almost everyday. At the very first sign of a cold, we make sure to start taking some echinacea; zinc lozenges also help to shorten the duration and severity of symptoms of the common cold.

Immune Boosting Fire Cider For Cold & Flu Season – I found the recipe for this cider on the Mountain Rose Herbs blog, and even though we haven’t tried it yet (it has to steep for 4 weeks!), I couldn’t wait to share it with you, so we can all try it together when it’s ready! It’s a lovely mixture of cider vinegar, ginger, horseradish, garlic, and other beneficial herbs and spices.

Natural Sore Throat & Cough Remedy – The combination of apple cider vinegar, raw honey, garlic, ginger, cayenne, and cinnamon makes this homemade cough syrup a potent remedy for that dry, scratchy throat and hacking cough that may accompany the common cold. This is stuff is pretty spicy (although you can modify it to cut the heat a bit), but it’s tasty and it works!

Natural Ways to Treat Headaches – Since the common cold doesn’t come alone, it usually brings along a few friends, one of which is headaches (or migraines). Most of the time, a headache is a sign of dehydration, so a tall glass of water should help, but for those times when it seems like nothing is working and you don’t want to reach for the OTC pain meds, these natural headache remedies are a good place to start.

Natural Ways to Treat Nausea – The common cold (or flu)’s other possible friend? Nausea. Sometimes that queasy feeling can take over and it feels like your stomach is turning into knots, and it’s everything you can possibly to keep yourself from just running to the bathroom. If you catch it early enough, there are quite a few natural ways to relieve that feeling of queasiness and nausea.

What are your natural ways for surviving the cold and flu season? What would you add to this list?

title: Get Moving 2013 Giveaway Hop {Blogger Opp}

content:
Blogger sign ups are now open for our GET MOVING 2013 Giveaway Event & Blog Hop!

The Get Moving 2013 Giveaway Event is bringing together bloggers with a passion for fitness, health & staying active! We’d like to give our readers the chance to win some really great “Get Moving” themed prizes just in time to support those New Year’s Resolutions! If you’re a blogger- sign up below. If you’re a reader- Watch for this Giveaway to start Jan. 17, 2013!

This Get Moving Giveaway event is sponsored by Silent Springs, A Lucky Ladybug, & Mommy of One & Counting. The event will run from Jan. 17th- 31st, 2013. Since this is a Get Moving themed giveaway, prizes can be anything related to fitness, health, & living an active lifestyle such as: running, biking, hiking, sports, weight training, rock climbing, disc golf, swimming, ice skating, skate boarding, etc. It could also include active play inspiring toys or kids gear such as: ride-ons, scoot bikes, mini trampolines, roller blades, scooters, helmets, strollers, baby carriers, etc

If you want to offer this giveaway to your readers, but don’t want to find a sponsor you may offer up the Grand Prize package. (More details to come.)

There will be a Grand Prize Giveaway as part of this event! Check back soon to see our growing list of sponsors!

**If you are a business or organization interested in sponsoring a prize in the Get Moving 2013 Giveaway Event please contact Info@SilentSprings.com**

Giveaway Details:

  • * Event starts at 12:01 AM EST on January 17, 2013 (Signs ups close Jan. 13)
  • * Event ends 11:59 PM EST January 31, 2013
  • * Individual blogger giveaway sign ups: Free!
  • * Links on Grand Prize RC: $3 first link, $1 each additional link (FB, TW, & PT options)
  • * Individual Blog Giveaway Requirements: $25 minimum prize value (1st link free with prize valued over $100!)
  • * Hashtag: #GetMoving2013

Blogger Sign ups:

  1. Fill out the google doc form HERE
  2. Complete the Linky form below.
  3. Grab one of the event buttons below and post on your blog (optional but we appreciate it!)
  4. Write a blog post & share about this event! You can write a short blog post about the giveaway or copy the code from our Get Moving Facebook Group for a pre-written post. (Please change it a bit for SEO purposes)
  5. Please Share on Facebook, Tweet about it, post it on your Pinterest page. Let’s make this HUGE!

Participation is free for individual blogger giveaways. If you would like to join in and have your links included on the Grand Prize Rafflecopter form, cost is $3 for the first link and $1 for each additional link. You may choose up to three links including Facebook, Twitter and Pinterest.
